play.title:
The Second Part of Henry the Fourth,
Containing his Death: and the Coronation
of King Henry the Fift.

speech.line: Open your Eares: For which of you will ſtop
The vent of Hearing, when loud Rumor ſpeakes?
I, from the Orient, to the drooping Weſt
(Making the winde my Poſt-horſe) ſtill vnfold
The Aƈts commenced on this Ball of Earth.
Vpon my Tongue, continuall Slanders ride,
The which, in euery Language, I pronounce,
Stuﬃng the Eares of them with falſe Reports:
I ſpeake of Peace, while couert Enmitie
(Vnder the ſmile of Safety) wounds the World:
And who but Rumour, who but onely I
Make fearfull Muſters, and prepar’d Defence,
Whil’ſt the bigge yeare, ſwolne with ſome other griefes,
Is thought with childe, by the ſterne Tyrant, Warre,
And no ſuch matter? Rumour, is a Pipe
Blowne by Surmiſes, Ielouſies, Conieƈtures;
And of ſo eaſie, and ſo plaine a ſtop,
That the blunt Monſter, with vncounted heads,
The ſtill diſcordant, wauering Multitude,
Can play vpon it. But what neede I thus
My well-knowne Body to Anathomize
Among my houſhold? Why is Rumour heere?
I run before King Harries viƈtory,
Who in a bloodie ﬁeld by Shrewsburie
Hath beaten downe yong Hotſpurre, and his Troopes,
Quenching the ﬂame of bold Rebellion,
Euen with the Rebels blood. But what meane I
To ſpeake ſo true at ﬁrſt? My Oﬃce is
To noyſe abroad, that Harry Monmouth fell
Vnder the Wrath of Noble Hotſpurres Sword:
And that the King, before the Dowglas Rage
Stoop’d his Annointed head, as low as death.
This haue I rumour’d through the peaſant-Townes,
Betweene the Royall Field of Shrewsburie,
And this Worme-eaten-Hole of ragged Stone,
Where Hotſpurres Father, old Northumberland,
Lyes crafty ſicke. The Poſtes come tyring on,
And not a man of them brings other newes
Then they haue learn’d of Me. From Rumours Tongues,
They bring ſmooth-Comforts-falſe, worſe then True-
wrongs.

scene.stagedir: Enter Lord Bardolfe, and the Porter.

speech.speaker: L. Bar.
speech.line: Who keepes the Gate heere hoa?
Where is the Earle?

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: What ſhall I ſay you are?

speech.speaker: Bar.
speech.line: Tell thou the Earle
That the Lord Bardolfe doth attend him heere.

speech.speaker: Por.
speech.line: His Lordſhip is walk’d forth into the Orchard,
Pleaſe it your Honor, knocke but at the Gate,
And he himſelfe will anſwer.

speech.speaker: L. Bar.
speech.line: Heere comes the Earle.

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: What newes Lord Bardolfe? Eu’ry minute now
Should be the Father of ſome Stratagem;
The Times are wilde: Contention (like a Horſe
Full of high Feeding) madly hath broke looſe,
And beares downe all before him.

speech.speaker: L. Bar.
speech.line: Noble Earle,
I bring you certaine newes from Shrewsbury.

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: Good, and heauen will.

speech.speaker: L. Bar.
speech.line: As good as heart can wiſh:
The King is almoſt wounded to the death:
And in the Fortune of my Lord your Sonne,
Prince Harrie ſlaine out-right: and both the Blunts
Kill’d by the hand of Dowglas. Yong Prince Iohn,
And Weſtmerland, and Staﬀord, ﬂed the Field.
And Harrie Monmouth’s Brawne (the Hulke Sir Iohn)
Is priſoner to your Sonne. O, ſuch a Day,
(So fought, ſo follow’d, and ſo fairely wonne)
Came not, till now, to digniﬁe the Times
Since Cæſars Fortunes.

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: How is this deriu’d?
Saw you the Field? Came you from Shrewsbury?

speech.speaker: L. Bar.
speech.line: I ſpake with one (my L.) that came frō thence,
A Gentleman well bred, and of good name,
That freely render’d me theſe newes for true.

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: Heere comes my Seruant Trauers, whom I ſent
On Tueſday laſt, to liſten after Newes.

speech.speaker: L. Bar.
speech.line: My Lord, I ouer-rod him on the way,
And he is furniſh’d with no certainties,
More then he (haply) may retaile from me.

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: Now Trauers, what good tidings comes frō you?

speech.speaker: Tra.
speech.line: My Lord, Sir Iohn Vmfreuill turn’d me backe
With ioyfull tydings; and (being better hors’d)
Out-rod me. After him, came ſpurring head
A Gentleman (almoſt fore-ſpent with ſpeed)
That ſtopp’d by me, to breath his bloodied horſe.
He ask’d the way to Cheſter: And of him
I did demand what Newes from Shrewsbury:
He told me, that Rebellion had ill lucke,
And that yong Harry Percies Spurre was cold.
With that he gaue his able Horſe the head,
And bending forwards ſtrooke his able heeles
Againſt the panting ſides of his poore Iade
Vp to the Rowell head, and ſtarting ſo,
He ſeem’d in running, to deuoure the way,
Staying no longer queſtion.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Ha? Againe:
Said he yong Harrie Percyes Spurre was cold?
(Of Hot-Spurre, cold-Spurre?) that Rebellion,
Had met ill lucke?

speech.speaker: L. Bar.
speech.line: My Lord: Ile tell you what,
If my yong Lord your Sonne, haue not the day,
Vpon mine Honor, for a ſilken point
Ile giue my Barony. Neuer talke of it.

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: Why ſhould the Gentleman that rode by Trauers
Giue then ſuch inſtances of Loſſe?

speech.speaker: L. Bar.
speech.line: Who, he?
He was ſome hielding Fellow, that had ſtolne
The Horſe he rode-on: and vpon my life
Speake at aduenture. Looke, here comes more Newes.

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: Yea, this mans brow, like to a Title-leafe,
Fore-tels the Nature of a Tragicke Volume:
So lookes the Strond, when the Imperious Flood
Hath left a witneſt Vſurpation.
Say Morton, did’ſt thou come from Shrewsbury?

speech.speaker: Mor.
speech.line: I ran from Shrewsbury (my Noble Lord)
Where hatefull death put on his vglieſt Maske
To fright our party.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: How doth my Sonne, and Brother?
Thou trembl’ſt; and the whiteneſſe in thy Cheeke
Is apter then thy Tongue, to tell thy Errand.
Euen ſuch a man, ſo faint, ſo ſpiritleſſe,
So dull, ſo dead in looke, ſo woe-be-gone,
Drew Priams Curtaine, in the dead of night,
And would haue told him, Halfe his Troy was burn’d.
But Priam found the Fire, ere he his Tongue:
And I, my Percies death, ere thou report’ſt it.
This, thou would’ſt ſay: Your Sonne did thus, and thus:
Your Brother, thus. So fought the Noble Dowglas,
Stopping my greedy eare, with their bold deeds.
But in the end (to ſtop mine Eare indeed)
Thou haſt a Sigh, to blow away this Praiſe,
Ending with Brother, Sonne, and all are dead.

speech.speaker: Mor.
speech.line: Dowglas is liuing, and your Brother, yet:
But for my Lord, your Sonne.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Why, he is dead.
See what a ready tongue Suſpition hath:
He that but feares the thing, he would not know,
Hath by Inſtinƈt, knowledge from others Eyes,
That what he feard, is chanc’d. Yet ſpeake (Morton)
Tell thou thy Earle, his Diuination Lies,
And I will take it, as a ſweet Diſgrace,
And make thee rich, for doing me ſuch wrong.

speech.speaker: Mor.
speech.line: You are too great, to be (by me) gainſaid:
Your Spirit is too true, your Feares too certaine.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Yet for all this, ſay not that Percies dead.
I ſee a ſtrange Confeſſion in thine Eye:
Thou ſhak’ſt thy head, and hold’ſt it Feare, or Sinne,
To ſpeake a truth. If he be ſlaine, ſay ſo:
The Tongue oﬀends not, that reports his death:
And he doth ſinne that doth belye the dead:
Not he, which ſayes the dead is not aliue:
Yet the ﬁrſt bringer of vnwelcome Newes
Hath but a looſing Oﬃce: and his Tongue,
Sounds euer after as a ſullen Bell
Remembred, knolling a departing Friend.

speech.speaker: L. Bar.
speech.line: I cannot thinke (my Lord) your ſon is dead.

speech.speaker: Mor.
speech.line: I am ſorry, I ſhould force you to beleeue
That, which I would to heauen, I had not ſeene.
But theſe mine eyes, ſaw him in bloody ſtate,
Rend’ring faint quittance (wearied, and out-breath’d)
To Henrie Monmouth, whoſe ſwift wrath beate downe
The neuer-daunted Percie to the earth,
From whence (with life) he neuer more ſprung vp.
In few; his death (whoſe ſpirit lent a ﬁre,
Euen to the dulleſt Peazant in his Campe)
Being bruited once, tooke ﬁre and heate away
From the beſt temper’d Courage in his Troopes.
For from his Mettle, was his Party ſteel’d;
Which once, in him abated, all the reſt
Turn’d on themſelues, like dull and heauy Lead:
And as the Thing, that’s heauy in it ſelfe,
Vpon enforcement, ﬂyes with greateſt ſpeede,
So did our Men, heauy in Hotſpurres loſſe,
Lend to this weight, ſuch lightneſſe with their Feare,
That Arrowes ﬂed not ſwifter toward their ayme,
Then did our Soldiers (ayming at their ſafety)
Fly from the ﬁeld. Then was that Noble Worceſter
Too ſoone ta’ne priſoner: and that furious Scot,
(The bloody Dowglas) whoſe well-labouring ſword
Had three times ſlaine th’ appearance of the King,
Gan vaile his ſtomacke, and did grace the ſhame
Of thoſe that turn’d their backes: and in his ﬂight,
Stumbling in Feare, was tooke. The ſumme of all,
Is, that the King hath wonne: and hath ſent out
A ſpeedy power, to encounter you my Lord,
Vnder the Conduƈt of yong Lancaſter
And Weſtmerland. This is the Newes at full.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: For this, I ſhall haue time enough to mourne.
In Poyſon, there is Phyſicke: and this newes
(Hauing beene well) that would haue made me ſicke,
Being ſicke, haue in ſome meaſure, made me well.
And as the Wretch, whoſe Feauer-weakned ioynts,
Like ſtrengthleſſe Hindges, buckle vnder life,
Impatient of his Fit, breakes like a ﬁre
Out of his keepers armes: Euen ſo, my Limbes
(Weak’ned with greefe) being now inrag’d with greefe,
Are thrice themſelues. Hence therefore thou nice crutch,
A ſcalie Gauntlet now, with ioynts of Steele
Muſt gloue this hand. And hence thou ſickly Quoife,
Thou art a guard too wanton for the head,
Which Princes, ﬂeſh’d with Conqueſt, ayme to hit.
Now binde my Browes with Iron and approach
The ragged’ſt houre, that Time and Spight dare bring
To frowne vpon th’ enrag’d Northumberland.
Let Heauen kiſſe Earth: now let not Natures hand
Keepe the wilde Flood conﬁn’d: Let Order dye,
And let the world no longer be a ſtage
To feede Contention in a ling’ring Aƈt:
But let one ſpirit of the Firſt-borne Caine
Reigne in all boſomes, that each heart being ſet
On bloody Courſes, the rude Scene may end,
And darkneſſe be the burier of the dead.

speech.speaker: L. Bar.
speech.line: Sweet Earle, diuorce not wiſedom from your Honor.

speech.speaker: Mor.
speech.line: The liues of all your louing Complices
Leane-on your health, the which if you giue-o’re
To ſtormy Paſſion, muſt perforce decay.
You caſt th’ euent of Warre (my Noble Lord)
And ſumm’d the accompt of Chance, before you ſaid
Let vs make head: It was your preſurmize,
That in the dole of blowes, your Son might drop.
You knew he walk’d o’re perils, on an edge
More likely to fall in, then to get o’re:
You were aduis’d his ﬂeſh was capeable
Of Wounds, and Scarres; and that his forward Spirit
Would lift him, where moſt trade of danger rang’d,
Yet did you ſay go forth: and none of this
(Though ſtrongly apprehended) could reſtraine
The ſtiﬀe-borne Aƈtion: What hath then befalne?
Or what hath this bold enterprize bring forth,
More then that Being, which was like to be?

speech.speaker: L. Bar.
speech.line: We all that are engaged to this loſſe,
Knew that we ventur’d on ſuch dangerous Seas,
That if we wrought out life, was ten to one:
And yet we ventur’d for the gaine propos’d,
Choak’d the reſpeƈt of likely perill fear’d,
And ſince we are o’re-ſet, venture againe.
Come, we will all put forth; Body, and Goods,

speech.speaker: Mor.
speech.line: ’Tis more then time: And (my moſt Noble Lord)
I heare for certaine, and do ſpeake the truth:
The gentle Arch-biſhop of Yorke is vp
With well appointed Powres: he is a man
Who with a double Surety bindes his Followers.
My Lord (your Sonne) had onely but the Corpes,
But ſhadowes, and the ſhewes of men to ﬁght.
For that ſame word (Rebellion) did diuide
The aƈtion of their bodies, from their ſoules,
And they did ﬁght with queaſineſſe, conſtrain’d
As men drinke Potions; that their Weapons only
Seem’d on our ſide: but for their Spirits and Soules,
This word (Rebellion) it had froze them vp,
As Fiſh are in a Pond. But now the Biſhop
Turnes Inſurreƈtion to Religion,
Suppos’d ſincere, and holy in his Thoughts:
He’s follow’d both with Body, and with Minde:
And doth enlarge his Riſing, with the blood
Of faire King Richard, ſcrap’d from Pomfret ſtones,
Deriues from heauen, his Quarrell, and his Cauſe:
Tels them, he doth beſtride a bleeding Land,
Gaſping for life, vnder great Bullingbrooke,
And more, and leſſe, do ﬂocke to follow him.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: I knew of this before. But to ſpeake truth,
This preſent greefe had wip’d it from my minde.
Go in with me, and councell euery man
The apteſt way for ſafety, and reuenge:
Get Poſts, and Letters, and make Friends with ſpeed,
Neuer ſo few, nor neuer yet more need.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Sirra, you giant, what ſaies the Doƈt. to my water?

speech.speaker: Pag.
speech.line: He ſaid ſir, the water it ſelfe was a good healthy
water: but for the party that ow’d it, he might haue more
diſeaſes then he knew for.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Men of all ſorts take a pride to gird at mee: the
braine of this fooliſh compounded Clay-man, is not able
to inuent any thing that tends to laughter, more then I
inuent, or is inuented on me. I am not onely witty in my
ſelfe, but the cauſe that wit is in other men. I doe heere
walke before thee, like a Sow, that hath o’rewhelm’d all
her Litter, but one. If the Prince put thee into my Ser-
uice for any other reaſon, then to ſet mee oﬀ, why then I
haue no iudgement. Thou horſon Mandrake, thou art
ﬁtter to be worne in my cap, then to wait at my heeles. I
was neuer mann’d with an Agot till now: but I will ſette
you neyther in Gold, nor Siluer, but in vilde apparell, and
ſend you backe againe to your Maſter, for a Iewell. The
Iuuenall (the Prince your Maſter) whoſe Chin is not yet
ﬂedg’d, I will ſooner haue a beard grow in the Palme of
my hand, then he ſhall get one on his cheeke: yet he will
not ſticke to ſay, his Face is a Face-Royall. Heauen may
ﬁniſh it when he will, it is not a haire amiſſe yet: he may
keepe it ſtill at a Face-Royall, for a Barber ſhall neuer
earne ſix pence out of it; and yet he will be crowing, as if
he had writ man euer ſince his Father was a Batchellour.
He may keepe his owne Grace, but he is almoſt out of
mine, I can aſſure him. What ſaid M. Dombledon, about
the Satten for my ſhort Cloake, and Slops?

speech.speaker: Pag.
speech.line: He ſaid ſir, you ſhould procure him better Aſſu-
rance, then Bardolfe: he wold not take his Bond & yours,
he lik’d not the Security.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Let him bee damn’d like the Glutton, may his
Tongue be hotter, a horſon Achitophel; a Raſcally-yea-
forſooth-knaue, to beare a Gentleman in hand, and then
ſtand vpon Security? The horſon ſmooth-pates doe now
weare nothing but high ſhoes, and bunches of Keyes at
their girdles: and if a man is through with them in ho-
neſt Taking-vp, then they muſt ſtand vpon Securitie: I
had as liefe they would put Rats-bane in my mouth, as
oﬀer to ſtoppe it with Security. I look’d hee ſhould haue
ſent me two and twenty yards of Satten (as I am true
Knight) and he ſends me Security. Well, he may ſleep in
Security, for he hath the horne of Abundance: and the
lightneſſe of his Wife ſhines through it, and yet cannot
he ſee, though he haue his owne Lanthorne to light him.
Where’s Bardolfe?

speech.speaker: Pag.
speech.line: He’s gone into Smithﬁeld to buy your worſhip
a horſe.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: I bought him in Paules, and hee’l buy mee a horſe
in Smithﬁeld. If I could get mee a wife in the Stewes, I
were Mann’d, Hors’d, and Wiu’d.

speech.speaker: Pag.
speech.line: Sir, heere comes the Nobleman that committed
the Prince for ſtriking him, about Bardolfe.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Wait cloſe, I will not ſee him.

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: What’s he that goes there?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Falſtaﬀe, and’t pleaſe your Lordſhip.

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: He that was in queſtion for the Robbery?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: He my Lord, but he hath ſince done good ſeruice
at Shrewsbury: and (as I heare) is now going with ſome
Charge, to the Lord Iohn of Lancaſter.

speech.speaker: Iuﬆ.
speech.line: What to Yorke? Call him backe againe.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Sir Iohn Falſtaﬀe.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Boy, tell him, I am deafe.

speech.speaker: Pag.
speech.line: You muſt ſpeake lowder, my Maſter is deafe.

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: I am ſure he is, to the hearing of any thing good.
Go plucke him by the Elbow, I muſt ſpeake with him.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Sir Iohn.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: What? a yong knaue and beg? Is there not wars? Is
there not imployment? Doth not the K. lack ſubieƈts? Do
not the Rebels want Soldiers? Though it be a ſhame to be
on any ſide but one, it is worſe ſhame to begge, then to
be on the worſt ſide, were it worſe then the name of Re-
bellion can tell how to make it.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: You miſtake me Sir.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Why ſir? Did I ſay you were an honeſt man? Set-
ting my Knight-hood, and my Souldierſhip aſide, I had
lyed in my throat, if I had ſaid ſo.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: I pray you (Sir) then ſet your Knighthood and
your Souldier-ſhip aſide, and giue mee leaue to tell you,
you lye in your throat, if you ſay I am any other then an
honeſt man.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: I giue thee leaue to tell me ſo? I lay a-ſide that
which growes to me? If thou get’ſt any leaue of me, hang
me: if thou tak’ſt leaue, thou wer’t better be hang’d: you
Hunt-counter, hence: Auant.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Sir, my Lord would ſpeake with you.

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: Sir Iohn Falſtaﬀe, a word with you.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: My good Lord: giue your Lordſhip good time of
the day. I am glad to ſee your Lordſhip abroad: I heard
ſay your Lordſhip was ſicke. I hope your Lordſhip goes
abroad by aduiſe. Your Lordſhip (though not clean paſt
your youth) hath yet ſome ſmack of age in you: ſome rel-
liſh of the ſaltneſſe of Time, and I moſt humbly beſeech
your Lordſhip, to haue a reuerend care of your health.

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: Sir Iohn, I ſent you before your Expedition, to
Shrewsburie.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: If it pleaſe your Lordſhip, I heare his Maieſtie is
return’d with ſome diſcomfort from Wales.

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: I talke not of his Maieſty: you would not come
when I ſent for you?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: And I heare moreouer, his Highneſſe is falne into
this ſame whorſon Apoplexie.

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: Well, heauen mend him. I pray let me ſpeak with you.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: This Apoplexie is (as I take it) a kind of Lethar-
gie, a ſleeping of the blood, a horſon Tingling.

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: What tell you me of it? be it as it is.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: It hath it originall from much greefe; from ſtudy
and perturbation of the braine. I haue read the cauſe of
his eﬀeƈts in Galen. It is a kinde of deafeneſſe.

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: I thinke you are falne into the diſeaſe: For you
heare not what I ſay to you.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Very well (my Lord) very well: rather an’t pleaſe
you) it is the diſeaſe of not Liſtning, the malady of not
Marking, that I am troubled withall.

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: To puniſh you by the heeles, would amend the
attention of your eares, & I care not if I be your Phyſitian

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: I am as poore as Iob, my Lord; but not ſo Patient:
your Lordſhip may miniſter the Potion of impriſonment
to me, in reſpeƈt of Pouertie: but how I ſhould bee your
Patient, to follow your preſcriptions, the wiſe may make
ſome dram of a ſcruple, or indeede, a ſcruple it ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: I ſent for you (when there were matters againſt
you for your life) to come ſpeake with me.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: As I was then aduiſed by my learned Councel, in
the lawes of this Land-ſeruice, I did not come.

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: Wel, the truth is (ſir Iohn) you liue in great infamy

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: He that buckles him in my belt, cānot liue in leſſe.

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: Your Meanes is very ſlender, and your waſt great.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: I would it were otherwiſe: I would my Meanes
were greater, and my waſte ſlenderer.

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: You haue miſled the youthfull Prince.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: The yong Prince hath miſled mee. I am the Fel-
low with the great belly, and he my Dogge.

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: Well, I am loth to gall a new-heal’d wound: your
daies ſeruice at Shrewsbury, hath a little gilded ouer
your Nights exploit on Gads-hill. You may thanke the
vnquiet time, for your quiet o’re-poſting that Aƈtion.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: My Lord?

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: But ſince all is wel, keep it ſo: wake not a ſleeping Wolfe.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: To wake a Wolfe, is as bad as to ſmell a Fox.

speech.speaker: Iu.
speech.line: What? you are as a candle, the better part burnt out

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: A Waſſell-Candle, my Lord; all Tallow: if I did
ſay of wax, my growth would approue the truth.

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: There is not a white haire on your face, but ſhold
haue his eﬀeƈt of grauity.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: His eﬀeƈt of grauy, grauy, grauy.

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: You follow the yong Prince vp and downe, like
his euill Angell.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Not ſo (my Lord) your ill Angell is light: but I
hope, he that lookes vpon mee, will take mee without,
weighing: and yet, in ſome reſpeƈts I grant, I cannot go:
I cannot tell. Vertue is of ſo little regard in theſe Coſtor-
mongers, that true valor is turn’d Beare-heard. Pregnan-
cie is made a Tapſter, and hath his quicke wit waſted in
giuing Recknings: all the other gifts appertinent to man
(as the malice of this Age ſhapes them) are not woorth a
Gooſeberry. You that are old, conſider not the capaci-
ties of vs that are yong: you meaſure the heat of our Li-
uers, with the bitternes of your gals: & we that are in the
vaward of our youth, I muſt confeſſe, are wagges too.

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: Do you ſet downe your name in the ſcrowle of
youth, that are written downe old, with all the Charrac-
ters of age? Haue you not a moiſt eye? a dry hand? a yel-
low cheeke? a white beard? a decreaſing leg? an increſing
belly? Is not your voice broken? your winde ſhort? your
wit ſingle? and euery part about you blaſted with Anti-
quity? and wil you cal your ſelfe yong? Fy, fy, fy, ſir Iohn.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: My Lord, I was borne with a white head, & ſom-
thing a round belly. For my voice, I haue loſt it with hal-
lowing and ſinging of Anthemes. To approue my youth
farther, I will not: the truth is, I am onely olde in iudge-
ment and vnderſtanding: and he that will caper with mee
for a thouſand Markes, let him lend me the mony, & haue
at him. For the boxe of th’ eare that the Prince gaue you,
he gaue it like a rude Prince, and you tooke it like a ſenſi-
ble Lord. I haue checkt him for it, and the yong Lion re-
pents: Marry not in aſhes and ſacke-cloath, but in new
Silke, and old Sacke.

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: Wel, heauen ſend the Prince a better companion.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Heauen ſend the Companion a better Prince: I
cannot rid my hands of him.

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: Well, the King hath ſeuer’d you and Prince Har-
ry, I heare you are going with Lord Iohn of Lancaſter, a-
gainſt the Archbiſhop, and the Earle of Northumberland

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Yes, I thanke your pretty ſweet wit for it: but
looke you pray, (all you that kiſſe my Ladie Peace, at
home) that our Armies ioyn not in a hot day: for if I take
but two ſhirts out with me, and I meane not to ſweat ex-
traordinarily: if it bee a hot day, if I brandiſh any thing
but my Bottle, would I might neuer ſpit white againe:
There is not a daungerous Aƈtion can peepe out his head,
but I am thruſt vpon it. Well, I cannot laſt euer.

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: Well, be honeſt, be honeſt, and heauen bleſſe your
Expedition.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Will your Lordſhip lend mee a thouſand pound,
to furniſh me forth?

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: Not a peny, not a peny: you are too impatient
to beare croſſes. Fare you well. Commend mee to my
Coſin Weſtmerland.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: If I do, ﬁllop me with a three-man-Beetle. A man
can no more ſeparate Age and Couetouſneſſe, then he can
part yong limbes and letchery: but the Gowt galles the
one, and the pox pinches the other; and ſo both the De-
grees preuent my curſes. Boy?

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: Sir.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: What money is in my purſe?

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: Seuen groats, and two pence.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: I can get no remedy againſt this Conſumption of
the purſe. Borrowing onely lingers, and lingers it out,
but the diſeaſe is incureable. Go beare this letter to my
Lord of Lancaſter, this to the Prince, this to the Earle of
Weſtmerland, and this to old Miſtris Vrſula, whome I
haue weekly ſworne to marry, ſince I perceiu’d the ﬁrſt
white haire on my chin. About it: you know where to
ﬁnde me. A pox of this Gowt, or a Gowt of this Poxe:
for the one or th’ other playes the rogue with my great
toe: It is no matter, if I do halt, I haue the warres for my
colour, and my Penſion ſhall ſeeme the more reaſonable.
A good wit will make vſe of any thing: I will turne diſ-
eaſes to commodity.

scene.stagedir: Enter Archbiſhop, Haſtings, Mowbray, and Lord Bardolfe.

speech.speaker: Ar.
speech.line: Thus haue you heard our cauſes, & kno our Means:
And my moſt noble Friends, I pray you all
Speake plainly your opinions of our hopes,
And ﬁrſt (Lord Marſhall) what ſay you to it?

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: I well allow the occaſion of our Armes,
But gladly would be better ſatisﬁed,
How (in our Meanes) we ſhould aduance our ſelues
To looke with forhead bold and big enough
Vpon the Power and puiſance of the King.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: Our preſent Muſters grow vpon the File
To ﬁue and twenty thouſand men of choice:
And our Supplies, liue largely in the hope
Of great Northumberland, whoſe boſome burnes
With an incenſed Fire of Iniuries.

speech.speaker: L. Bar.
speech.line: The queſtion then (Lord Haﬆings) ſtandeth thus
Whether our preſent ﬁue and twenty thouſand
May hold-vp-head, without Northumberland:

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: With him, we may.

speech.speaker: L. Bar.
speech.line: I marry, there’s the point:
But if without him we be thought to feeble,
My iudgement is, we ſhould not ſtep too farre
Till we had his Aſsiſtance by the hand.
For in a Theame ſo bloody fac’d, as this,
Conieƈture, Expeƈtation, and Surmiſe
Of Aydes incertaine, ſhould not be admitted.

speech.speaker: Arch.
speech.line: ’Tis very true Lord Bardolfe, for indeed
It was yong Hotſpurres caſe, at Shrewsbury.

speech.speaker: L. Bar.
speech.line: It was (my Lord) who lin’d himſelf with hope,
Eating the ayre, on promiſe of Supply,
Flatt’ring himſelfe with Proieƈt of a power,
Much ſmaller, then the ſmalleſt of his Thoughts,
And ſo with great imagination
(Proper to mad men) led his Powers to death,
And (winking) leap’d into deſtruƈtion.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: But (by your leaue) it neuer yet did hurt,
To lay downe likely-hoods, and formes of hope.

speech.speaker: L. Bar.
speech.line: Yes, if this preſent quality of warre,
Indeed the inſtant aƈtion: a cauſe on foot,
Liues ſo in hope: As in an early Spring,
We ſee th’ appearing buds, which to proue fruite,
Hope giues not ſo much warrant, as Diſpaire
That Froſts will bite them. When we meane to build,
We ﬁrſt ſuruey the Plot, then draw the Modell,
And when we ſee the ﬁgure of the houſe,
Then muſt we rate the coſt of the Ereƈtion,
Which if we ﬁnde out-weighes Ability,
What do we then, but draw a-new the Modell
In fewer oﬃces? Or at leaſt, deſiſt
To builde at all? Much more, in this great worke,
(Which is (almoſt) to plucke a Kingdome downe,
And ſet another vp) ſhould we ſuruey
The plot of Situation, and the Modell;
Conſent vpon a ſure Foundation:
Queſtion Surueyors, know our owne eſtate,
How able ſuch a Worke to vndergo,
To weigh againſt his Oppoſite? Or elſe,
We fortiﬁe in Paper, and in Figures,
Vſing the Names of men, inſtead of men:
Like one, that drawes the Modell of a houſe
Beyond his power to builde it; who (halfe through)
Giues o’re, and leaues his part-created Coſt
A naked ſubieƈt to the Weeping Clouds,
And waſte, for churliſh Winters tyranny.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: Grant that our hopes (yet likely of faire byrth)
Should be ſtill-borne: and that we now poſſeſt
The vtmoſt man of expeƈtation:
I thinke we are a Body ſtrong enough
(Euen as we are) to equall with the King.

speech.speaker: L. Bar.
speech.line: What is the King but ﬁue & twenty thouſand?

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: To vs no more: nay not ſo much Lord Bardolf.
For his diuiſions (as the Times do braul)
Are in three Heads: one Power againſt the French,
And one againſt Glendower: Perforce a third
Muſt take vp vs: So is the vnﬁrme King
In three diuided: and his Coﬀers ſound
With hollow Pouerty, and Emptineſſe.

speech.speaker: Ar.
speech.line: That he ſhould draw his ſeuerall ſtrengths togither
And come againſt vs in full puiſſance
Need not be dreaded.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: If he ſhould do ſo,
He leaues his backe vnarm’d, the French, and Welch
Baying him at the heeles: neuer feare that.

speech.speaker: L. Bar.
speech.line: Who is it like ſhould lead his Forces hither?

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: The Duke of Lancaſter, and Weſtmerland:
Againſt the Welſh himſelfe, and Harrie Monmouth.
But who is ſubſtituted ’gainſt the French,
I haue no certaine notice.

speech.speaker: Arch.
speech.line: Let vs on:
And publiſh the occaſion of our Armes.
The Common-wealth is ſicke of their owne Choice,
Their ouer-greedy loue hath ſurfetted:
An habitation giddy, and vnſure
Hath he that buildeth on the vulgar heart.
O thou fond Many, with what loud applauſe
Did’ſt thou beate heauen with bleſſing Bullingbrooke,
Before he was, what thou would’ſt haue him be?
And being now trimm’d in thine owne deſires,
Thou (beaſtly Feeder) art ſo full of him,
That thou prouok’ſt thy ſelfe to caſt him vp.
So, ſo, (thou common Dogge) did’ſt thou diſgorge
Thy glutton-boſome of the Royall Richard,
And now thou would’ſt eate thy dead vomit vp,
And howl’ſt to ﬁnde it. What truſt is in theſe Times?
They, that when Richard liu’d, would haue him dye,
Are now become enamour’d on his graue.
Thou that threw’ſt duſt vpon his goodly head
When through proud London he came ſighing on,
After th’ admired heeles of Bullingbrooke,
Cri’ſt now, O Earth, yeeld vs that King againe,
And take thou this (O thoughts of men accurs’d)
“Paſt, and to Come, ſeemes beſt; things Preſent, worſt.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: Shall we go draw our numbers, and ſet on?

speech.speaker: Haﬆ.
speech.line: We are Times ſubieƈts, and Time bids, be gon.

scene.stagedir: Enter Hoſteſſe, with two Oﬀicers, Fang, and Snare.

speech.speaker: Hoﬆeſſe.
speech.line: Mr. Fang, haue you entred the Aƈtion?

speech.speaker: Fang.
speech.line: It is enter’d.

speech.speaker: Hoﬆeſſe.
speech.line: Wher’s your Yeoman? Is it a luſty yeoman?
Will he ſtand to it?

speech.speaker: Fang.
speech.line: Sirrah, where’s Snare?

speech.speaker: Hoﬆeſſe.
speech.line: I, I, good M. Snare.

speech.speaker: Snare.
speech.line: Heere, heere.

speech.speaker: Fang.
speech.line: Snare, we muſt Arreſt Sir Iohn Falſtaﬀe.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: I good M. Snare, I haue enter’d him, and all.

speech.speaker: Sn.
speech.line: It may chance coſt ſome of vs our liues: he wil ſtab

speech.speaker: Hoſteſſe.
speech.line: Alas the day: take heed of him: he ſtabd me
in mine owne houſe, and that moſt beaſtly: he cares not
what miſcheefe he doth, if his weapon be out. Hee will
foyne like any diuell, he will ſpare neither man, woman,
nor childe.

speech.speaker: Fang.
speech.line: If I can cloſe with him, I care not for his thruſt.

speech.speaker: Hoﬆeſſe.
speech.line: No, nor I neither: Ile be at your elbow.

speech.speaker: Fang.
speech.line: If I but ﬁſt him once: if he come but within my
Vice.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: I am vndone with his going: I warrant he is an
inﬁnitiue thing vpon my ſcore. Good M. Fang hold him
ſure: good M. Snare let him not ſcape, he comes continu-
antly to Py-Corner (ſauing your manhoods) to buy a ſad-
dle, and hee is indited to dinner to the Lubbars head in
Lombard ſtreet, to M. Smoothes the Silkman. I pra’ ye, ſince
my Exion is enter’d, and my Caſe ſo openly known to the
world, let him be brought in to his anſwer: A 100. Marke
is a long one, for a poore lone woman to beare: & I haue
borne, and borne, and borne, and haue bin fub’d oﬀ, and
fub’d-oﬀ, from this day to that day, that it is a ſhame to
be thought on. There is no honeſty in ſuch dealing, vnles
a woman ſhould be made an Aſſe and a Beaſt, to beare e-
uery Knaues wrong. Enter Falſtaﬀe and Bardolfe.
Yonder he comes, and that arrant Malmeſey-Noſe Bar-
dolfe with him. Do your Oﬃces, do your oﬃces: M. Fang,
& M. Snare, do me, do me, do me your Oﬃces.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: How now? whoſe Mare’s dead? what’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Fang.
speech.line: Sir Iohn, I arreſt you, at the ſuit of Miſt. Quickly.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Away Varlets, draw Bardolfe: Cut me oﬀ the
Villaines head: throw the Queane in the Channel.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: Throw me in the channell? Ile throw thee there.
Wilt thou? wilt thou? thou baſtardly rogue. Murder, mur-
der, O thou Hony-ſuckle villaine, wilt thou kill Gods of-
ﬁcers, and the Kings? O thou hony-ſeed Rogue, thou art
a honyſeed, a Man-queller, and a woman-queller.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Keep them oﬀ, Bardolfe.

speech.speaker: Fang.
speech.line: A reſcu, a reſcu.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: Good people bring a reſcu. Thou wilt not? thou
wilt not? Do, do thou Rogue: Do thou Hempſeed.

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: Away you Scullion, you Rampallian, you Fuſtil-
lirian: Ile tucke your Cataſtrophe.

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: What’s the matter? Keepe the Peace here, hoa.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: Good my Lord be good to mee. I beſeech you
ſtand to me.

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: How now ſir Iohn? What are you brauling here?
Doth this become your place, your time, and buſineſſe?
You ſhould haue bene well on your way to Yorke.
Stand from him Fellow; wherefore hang’ſt vpon him?

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: Oh my moſt worſhipfull Lord, and’t pleaſe your
Grace, I am a poore widdow of Eaſtcheap, and he is arre-
ſted at my ſuit.

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: For what ſumme?

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: It is more then for ſome (my Lord) it is for all: all
I haue, he hath eaten me out of houſe and home; hee hath
put all my ſubſtance into that fat belly of his: but I will
haue ſome of it out againe, or I will ride thee o’ Nights,
like the Mare.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: I thinke I am as like to ride the Mare, if I haue
any vantage of ground, to get vp.

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: How comes this, Sir Iohn? Fy, what a man of
good temper would endure this tempeſt of exclamation?
Are you not aſham’d to inforce a poore Widdowe to ſo
rough a courſe, to come by her owne?

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: What is the groſſe ſumme that I owe thee?

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: Marry (if thou wer’t an honeſt man) thy ſelfe, &
the mony too. Thou didſt ſweare to mee vpon a parcell
gilt Goblet, ſitting in my Dolphin-chamber at the round
table, by a ſea-cole ﬁre, on Wedneſday in Whitſon week,
when the Prince broke thy head for lik’ning him to a ſin-
ging man of Windſor; Thou didſt ſweare to me then (as I
was waſhing thy wound) to marry me, and make mee my
Lady thy wife. Canſt ӳ deny it? Did not goodwife Keech
the Butchers wife come in then, and cal me goſſip Quick-
ly? comming in to borrow a meſſe of Vinegar: telling vs,
ſhe had a good diſh of Prawnes: whereby ӳ didſt deſire to
eat ſome: whereby I told thee they were ill for a greene
wound? And didſt not thou (when ſhe was gone downe
ſtaires) deſire me to be no more familiar with ſuch poore
people, ſaying, that ere long they ſhould call me Madam?
And did’ſt ӳ not kiſſe me, and bid mee fetch thee 30.s? I
put thee now to thy Book-oath, deny it if thou canſt?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: My Lord, this is a poore mad ſoule: and ſhe ſayes
vp & downe the town, that her eldeſt ſon is like you. She
hath bin in good caſe, & the truth is, pouerty hath diſtra-
ƈted her: but for theſe fooliſh Oﬃcers, I beſeech you, I
may haue redreſſe againſt them.

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: Sir Iohn, ſir Iohn, I am well acquainted with your
maner of wrenching the true cauſe, the falſe way. It is not
a conﬁdent brow, nor the throng of wordes, that come
with ſuch (more then impudent) ſawcines from you, can
thruſt me from a leuell conſideration, I know you ha’ pra-
ƈtis’d vpon the eaſie-yeelding ſpirit of this woman.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: Yes in troth my Lord.

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: Prethee peace: pay her the debt you owe her, and
vnpay the villany you haue done her: the one you may do
with ſterling mony, & the other with currant repentance.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: My Lord, I will not vndergo this ſneape without
reply. You call honorable Boldnes, Impudent Sawcineſſe:
If a man wil curt’ſie, and ſay nothing, he is vertuous: No,
my Lord (your humble duty remēbred) I will not be your
ſutor. I ſay to you, I deſire deliu’rance from theſe Oﬃcers
being vpon haſty employment in the Kings Aﬀaires.

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: You ſpeake, as hauing power to do wrong: But
anſwer in the eﬀeƈt of your Reputation, and ſatisﬁe the
poore woman.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Come hither Hoſteſſe.

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: Now Maſter Gower; What newes?

speech.speaker: Gow.
speech.line: The King (my Lord) and Henrie Prince of Wales
Are neere at hand: The reſt the Paper telles.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: As I am a Gentleman.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: Nay, you ſaid ſo before.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: As I am a Gentleman. Come, no more words of it

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: By this Heauenly ground I tread on, I muſt be
faine to pawne both my Plate, and the Tapiſtry of my dy-
ning Chambers.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Glaſſes, glaſſes, is the onely drinking: and for
thy walles a pretty ſlight Drollery, or the Storie of the
Prodigall, or the Germane hunting in Waterworke, is
worth a thouſand of theſe Bed-hangings, and theſe Fly-
bitten Tapiſtries. Let it be tenne pound (if thou canſt.)
Come, if it were not for thy humors, there is not a better
Wench in England. Go, waſh thy face, and draw thy
Aƈtion: Come, thou muſt not bee in this humour with
me, come, I know thou was’t ſet on to this.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: Prethee (Sir Iohn) let it be but twenty Nobles,
I loath to pawne my Plate, in good earneſt la.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Let it alone, Ile make other ſhift: you’l be a fool
ſtill.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: Well, you ſhall haue it although I pawne my
Gowne. I hope you’l come to Supper: You’l pay me al-
together?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Will I liue? Go with her, with her: hooke-on,
hooke-on.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: Will you haue Doll Teare-ſheet meet you at ſup-
per?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: No more words. Let’s haue her.

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuﬆ.
speech.line: I haue heard bitter newes.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: What’s the newes (my good Lord?)

speech.speaker: Ch. Iu.
speech.line: Where lay the King laſt night?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: At Baſingſtoke my Lord.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: I hope (my Lord) all’s well. What is the newes
my Lord?

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: Come all his Forces backe?

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: No: Fifteene hundred Foot, ﬁue hundred Horſe
Are march’d vp to my Lord of Lancaſter,
Againſt Northumberland, and the Archbiſhop.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Comes the King backe from Wales, my noble L?

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: You ſhall haue Letters of me preſently.
Come, go along with me, good M. Gowre.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Maſter Gowre, ſhall I entreate you with mee to
dinner?

speech.speaker: Gow.
speech.line: I muſt waite vpon my good Lord heere.
I thanke you, good Sir Iohn.

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: Sir Iohn, you loyter heere too long being you
are to take Souldiers vp, in Countries as you go.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Will you ſup with me, Maſter Gowre?

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: What fooliſh Maſter taught you theſe man-
ners, Sir Iohn?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Maſter Gower, if they become mee not, hee was a
Foole that taught them mee. This is the right Fencing
grace (my Lord) tap for tap, and ſo part faire.

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: Now the Lord lighten thee, thou art a great
Foole.

scene.stagedir: Enter Prince Henry, Pointz, Bardolfe, and Page.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Truſt me, I am exceeding weary.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Is it come to that? I had thought wearines durſt
not haue attach’d one of ſo high blood.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: It doth me: though it diſcolours the complexion
of my Greatneſſe to acknowledge it. Doth it not ſhew
vildely in me, to deſire ſmall Beere?

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Why, a Prince ſhould not be ſo looſely ſtudied,
as to remember ſo weake a Compoſition.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Belike then, my Appetite was not Princely
got: for (in troth) I do now remember the poore Crea-
ture, Small Beere. But indeede theſe humble conſidera-
tions make me out of loue with my Greatneſſe. What a
diſgrace is it to me, to remember thy name? Or to know
thy face to morrow? Or to take note how many paire of
Silk ſtockings ӳ haſt? (Viz. theſe, and thoſe that were thy
peach-colour’d ones:) Or to beare the Inuentorie of thy
ſhirts, as one for ſuperﬂuity, and one other, for vſe. But
that the Tennis-Court-keeper knowes better then I, for
it is a low ebbe of Linnen with thee, when thou kept’ſt
not Racket there, as thou haſt not done a great while, be-
cauſe the reſt of thy Low Countries, haue made a ſhift to
eate vp thy Holland.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: How ill it followes, after you haue labour’d ſo
hard, you ſhould talke ſo idlely? Tell me how many good
yong Princes would do ſo, their Fathers lying ſo ſicke, as
yours is?

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Shall I tell thee one thing, Pointz?

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Yes: and let it be an excellent good thing.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: It ſhall ſerue among wittes of no higher breed-
ing then thine.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Go to: I ſtand the puſh of your one thing, that
you’l tell.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Why, I tell thee, it is not meet, that I ſhould be
ſad now my Father is ſicke: albeit I could tell to thee (as
to one it pleaſes me, for fault of a better, to call my friend)
I could be ſad, and ſad indeed too.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Very hardly, vpon ſuch a ſubieƈt.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Thou think’ſt me as farre in the Diuels Booke, as
thou, and Falſtaﬀe, for obduracie and perſiſtencie. Let the
end try the man. But I tell thee, my hart bleeds inward-
ly, that my Father is ſo ſicke: and keeping ſuch vild com-
pany as thou art, hath in reaſon taken from me, all oſten-
tation of ſorrow.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: The reaſon?

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: What would’ſt thou think of me, if I ſhold weep?

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: I would thinke thee a moſt Princely hypocrite.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: It would be euery mans thought: and thou art
a bleſſed Fellow, to thinke as euery man thinkes: neuer a
mans thought in the world, keepes the Rode-way better
then thine: euery man would thinke me an Hypocrite in-
deede. And what accites your moſt worſhipful thought
to thinke ſo?

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Why, becauſe you haue beene ſo lewde, and ſo
much ingraﬀed to Falſtaﬀe.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: And to thee.

speech.speaker: Pointz.
speech.line: Nay, I am well ſpoken of, I can heare it with
mine owne eares: the worſt that they can ſay of me is, that
I am a ſecond Brother, and that I am a proper Fellowe of
my hands: and thoſe two things I confeſſe I canot helpe.
Looke, looke, here comes Bardolfe.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: And the Boy that I gaue Falſtaﬀe, he had him
from me Chriſtian, and ſee if the fat villain haue not trans
form’d him Ape.

speech.speaker: Bar.
speech.line: Saue your Grace.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: And yours, moſt Noble Bardolfe.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Come you pernitious Aſſe, you baſhfull Foole,
muſt you be bluſhing? Wherefore bluſh you now? what
a Maidenly man at Armes are you become? Is it ſuch a
matter to get a Pottle-pots Maiden-head?

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: He call’d me euen now (my Lord) through a red
Lattice, and I could diſcerne no part of his face from the
window: at laſt I ſpy’d his eyes, and me thought he had
made two holes in the Ale-wiues new Petticoat, & pee-
ped through.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Hath not the boy proﬁted?

speech.speaker: Bar.
speech.line: Away, you horſon vpright Rabbet, away.

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: Away, you raſcally Altheas dreame, away.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Inſtruƈt vs Boy: what dreame, Boy?

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: Marry (my Lord) Althea dream’d, ſhe was de-
liuer’d of a Firebrand, and therefore I call him hir dream.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: A Crownes-worth of good Interpretation:
There it is, Boy.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: O that this good Bloſſome could bee kept from
Cankers: Well, there is ſix pence to preſerue thee.

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: If you do not make him be hang’d among you,
the gallowes ſhall be wrong’d.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: And how doth thy Maſter, Bardolph?

speech.speaker: Bar.
speech.line: Well, my good Lord: he heard of your Graces
comming to Towne. There’s a Letter for you.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Deliuer’d with good reſpeƈt: And how doth the
Martlemas, your Maſter?

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: In bodily health Sir.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Marry, the immortall part needes a Phyſitian:
but that moues not him: though that bee ſicke, it dyes
not.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: I do allow this Wen to bee as familiar with
me, as my dogge: and he holds his place, for looke you
he writes.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Letter. Iohn Falſtaﬀe Knight: (Euery man muſt
know that, as oft as hee hath occaſion to name himſelfe:)
Euen like thoſe that are kinne to the King, for they neuer
pricke their ﬁnger, but they ſay, there is ſom of the kings
blood ſpilt. How comes that (ſayes he) that takes vpon
him not to conceiue? the anſwer is as ready as a borrow-
ed cap: I am the Kings poore Coſin, Sir.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Nay, they will be kin to vs, but they wil fetch
it from Iaphet. But to the Letter: — Sir Iohn Falſtaﬀe,

line.recite: Knight, to the Sonne of the King, neereſt his Father, Harrie

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Why this is a Certiﬁcate.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Peace.

line.recite: I will imitate the honourable Romaines in breuitie.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Sure he meanes breuity in breath: ſhort-winded.

line.recite: I commend me to thee, I commend thee, and I leaue thee. Bee
not too familiar with Pointz, for hee miſuſes thy Fauours ſo
much, that he ſweares thou art to marrie his Siſter Nell. Re-
pent at idle times as thou mayſt, and ſo farewell.
Thine, by yea and no: which is as much as to ſay, as thou
vſeſt him. Iacke Falſtaﬀe with my Familiars:
Iohn with my Brothers and Siſter: & Sir

speech.line: My Lord, I will ſteepe this Letter in Sack, and make him
eate it.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: That’s to make him eate twenty of his Words.
But do you vſe me thus Ned? Muſt I marry your Siſter?

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: May the Wench haue no worſe Fortune. But I
neuer ſaid ſo.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Well, thus we play the Fooles with the time, &
the ſpirits of the wiſe, ſit in the clouds, and mocke vs: Is
your Maſter heere in London?

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: Yes my Lord.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Where ſuppes he? Doth the old Bore, feede in
the old Franke?

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: At the old place my Lord, in Eaſt-cheape.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: What Company?

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: Epheſians my Lord, of the old Church.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Sup any women with him?

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: None my Lord, but old Miſtris Quickly, and M.
Doll Teare-ſheet.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: What Pagan may that be?

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: A proper Gentlewoman, Sir, and a Kinſwoman
of my Maſters.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Euen ſuch Kin, as the Pariſh Heyfors are to the
Towne-Bull?
Shall we ſteale vpon them (Ned) at Supper?

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: I am your ſhadow, my Lord, Ile follow you.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Sirrah, you boy, and Bardolph, no word to your
Maſter that I am yet in Towne.
There’s for your ſilence.

speech.speaker: Bar.
speech.line: I haue no tongue, ſir.

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: And for mine Sir, I will gouerne it.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Fare ye well: go.
This Doll Teare-ſheet ſhould be ſome Rode.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: I warrant you, as common as the way betweene
S. Albans, and London.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: How might we ſee Falſtaﬀe beſtow himſelfe to
night, in his true colours, and not our ſelues be ſeene?

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Put on two Leather Ierkins, and Aprons, and
waite vpon him at his Table, like Drawers.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: From a God, to a Bull? A heauie declenſion: It
was Ioues caſe. From a Prince, to a Prentice, a low tranſ-
formation, that ſhall be mine: for in euery thing, the pur-
poſe muſt weigh with the folly. Follow me Ned.

scene.stagedir: Enter Northumberland, his Ladie, and Harrie Percies Ladie.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: I prethee louing Wife, and gentle Daughter,
Giue an euen way vnto my rough Aﬀaires:
Put not you on the viſage of the Times,
And be like them to Percie, troubleſome.

speech.speaker: Wife.
speech.line: I haue giuen ouer, I will ſpeak no more,
Do what you will: your Wiſedome, be your guide.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Alas (ſweet Wife) my Honor is at pawne,
And but my going, nothing can redeeme it.

speech.speaker: La.
speech.line: Oh yet, for heauens ſake, go not to theſe Warrs;
The Time was (Father) when you broke your word,
When you were more endeer’d to it, then now,
When your owne Percy, when my heart-deere Harry,
Threw many a Northward looke, to ſee his Father
Bring vp his Powres: but he did long in vaine.
Who then perſwaded you to ſtay at home?
There were two Honors loſt; Yours, and your Sonnes.
For Yours, may heauenly glory brighten it:
For His, it ſtucke vpon him, as the Sunne
In the gray vault of Heauen: and by his Light
Did all the Cheualrie of England moue
To do braue Aƈts. He was (indeed) the Glaſſe
Wherein the Noble-Youth did dreſſe themſelues.
He had no Legges, that praƈtic’d not his Gate:
And ſpeaking thicke (which Nature made his blemiſh)
Became the Accents of the Valiant.
For thoſe that could ſpeake low, and tardily,
Would turne their owne Perfeƈtion, to Abuſe,
To ſeeme like him. So that in Speech, in Gate,
In Diet, in Aﬀeƈtions of delight,
In Militarie Rules, Humors of Blood,
He was the Marke, and Glaſſe, Coppy, and Booke,
That faſhion’d others. And him, O wondrous! him,
O Miracle of Men! Him did you leaue
(Second to none) vn-ſeconded by you,
To looke vpon the hideous God of Warre,
In diſ-aduantage, to abide a ﬁeld,
Where nothing but the ſound of Hotſpurs Name
Did ſeeme defenſible: ſo you left him.
Neuer, O neuer doe his Ghoſt the wrong,
To hold your Honor more preciſe and nice
With others, then with him. Let them alone:
The Marſhall and the Arch-biſhop are ſtrong.
Had my ſweet Harry had but halfe their Numbers,
To day might I (hanging on Hotſpurs Necke)
Haue talk’d of Monmouth’s Graue.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Beſhrew your heart,
(Faire Daughter) you doe draw my Spirits from me,
With new lamenting ancient Ouer-ſights.
But I muſt goe, and meet with Danger there,
Or it will ſeeke me in another place,
And ﬁnde me worſe prouided.

speech.speaker: Wife.
speech.line: O ﬂye to Scotland,
Till that the Nobles, and the armed Commons,
Haue of their Puiſſance made a little taſte.

speech.speaker: Lady.
speech.line: If they get ground, and vantage of the King,
Then ioyne you with them, like a Ribbe of Steele,
To make Strength ſtronger. But, for all our loues,
Firſt let them trye themſelues. So did your Sonne,
He was ſo ſuﬀer’d; ſo came I a Widow:
And neuer ſhall haue length of Life enough,
To raine vpon Remembrance with mine Eyes,
That it may grow, and ſprowt, as high as Heauen,
For Recordation to my Noble Husband.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Come, come, go in with me: ’tis with my Minde
As with the Tyde, ſwell’d vp vnto his height,
That makes a ſtill-ſtand, running neyther way.
Faine would I goe to meet the Arch-biſhop,
But many thouſand Reaſons hold me backe.
I will reſolue for Scotland: there am I,
Till Time and Vantage craue my company.

speech.speaker: 1. Drawer.
speech.line: What haſt thou brought there? Apple-
Iohns? Thou know’ſt Sir Iohn cannot endure an Apple-
Iohn.

speech.speaker: 2. Draw.
speech.line: Thou ſay’ſt true: the Prince once ſet a Diſh
of Apple-Iohns before him, and told him there were ﬁue
more Sir Iohns: and, putting oﬀ his Hat, ſaid, I will now
take my leaue of theſe ſixe drie, round, old-wither’d
Knights. It anger’d him to the heart: but hee hath for-
got that.

speech.speaker: 1. Draw.
speech.line: Why then couer, and ſet them downe: and
ſee if thou canſt ﬁnde out Sneakes Noyſe; Miſtris Teare-
ſheet would faine haue ſome Muſique.

speech.speaker: 2. Draw.
speech.line: Sirrha, heere will be the Prince, and Maſter
Points, anon: and they will put on two of our Ierkins,
and Aprons, and Sir Iohn muſt not know of it: Bardolph
hath brought word.

speech.speaker: 1. Draw.
speech.line: Then here will be old Vtis: it will be an ex-
cellent ſtratagem.

speech.speaker: 2. Draw
speech.line: Ile ſee if I can ﬁnde out Sneake.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: Sweet-heart, me thinkes now you are in an ex-
cellent good temperalitie: your Pulſidge beates as ex-
traordinarily, as heart would deſire; and your Colour
(I warrant you) is as red as any Roſe: But you haue
drunke too much Canaries, and that’s a maruellous ſear-
ching Wine; and it perfumes the blood, ere wee can ſay
what’s this. How doe you now?

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Better then I was: Hem.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: Why that was well ſaid: A good heart’s worth
Gold. Looke, here comes Sir Iohn.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: When Arthur ﬁrſt in Court — (emptie the Iordan)
and was a worthy King: How now Miſtris Dol?

speech.speaker: Hoﬆ.
speech.line: Sick of a Calme: yea, good-ſooth.

speech.speaker: Falﬆ.
speech.line: So is all her Seƈt: if they be once in a Calme,
they are ſick.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: You muddie Raſcall, is that all the comfort you
giue me?

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: You make fat Raſcalls, Miſtris Dol.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: I make them? Gluttonie and Diſeaſes make
them, I make them not.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: If the Cooke make the Gluttonie, you helpe to
make the Diſeaſes (Dol) we catch of you (Dol) we catch
of you: Grant that, my poore Vertue, grant that.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: I marry, our Chaynes, and our Iewels.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Your Brooches, Pearles, and Owches: For to
ſerue brauely, is to come halting oﬀ: you know, to come
oﬀ the Breach, with his Pike bent brauely, and to Surge-
rie brauely; to venture vpon the charg’d-Chambers
brauely.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: Why this is the olde faſhion: you two neuer
meete, but you fall to ſome diſcord: you are both (in
good troth) as Rheumatike as two drie Toſtes, you can-
not one beare with anothers Conﬁrmities. What the
good-yere? One muſt beare, and that muſt bee you:
you are the weaker Veſſell; as they ſay, the emptier
Veſſell.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Can a weake emptie Veſſell beare ſuch a huge
full Hogs-head? There’s a whole Marchants Venture
of Burdeux-Stuﬀe in him: you haue not ſeene a Hulke
better ſtuﬀt in the Hold. Come, Ile be friends with thee
Iacke: Thou art going to the Warres, and whether I
ſhall euer ſee thee againe, or no, there is no body
cares.

speech.speaker: Drawer.
speech.line: Sir, Ancient Piﬆoll is below, and would
ſpeake with you.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Hang him, ſwaggering Raſcall, let him not
come hither: it is the foule-mouth’dſt Rogue in Eng-
land.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: If hee ſwagger, let him not come here: I muſt
liue amongſt my Neighbors, Ile no Swaggerers: I am
in good name, and fame, with the very beſt: ſhut the
doore, there comes no Swaggerers heere: I haue not
liu’d all this while, to haue ſwaggering now: ſhut the
doore, I pray you.

speech.speaker: Falﬆ.
speech.line: Do’ſt thou heare, Hoſteſſe?

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: ’Pray you paciﬁe your ſelfe (Sir Iohn) there comes
no Swaggerers heere.

speech.speaker: Falﬆ.
speech.line: Do’ſt thou heare? it is mine Ancient.

speech.speaker: Hoﬆ.
speech.line: Tilly-fally (Sir Iohn) neuer tell me, your ancient
Swaggerer comes not in my doores. I was before Maſter
Tiſick the Deputie, the other day: and as hee ſaid to me,
it was no longer agoe then Wedneſday laſt: Neighbour
Quickly (ſayes hee;) Maſter Dombe, our Miniſter, was by
then: Neighbour Quickly (ſayes hee) receiue thoſe that
are Ciuill; for (ſayth hee) you are in an ill Name: now
hee ſaid ſo, I can tell whereupon: for (ſayes hee) you are
an honeſt Woman, and well thought on; therefore take
heede what Gueſts you receiue: Receiue (ſayes hee) no
ſwaggering Companions. There comes none heere. You
would bleſſe you to heare what hee ſaid. No, Ile no
Swaggerers.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Hee’s no Swaggerer (Hoſteſſe:) a tame Cheater,
hee: you may ſtroake him as gently, as a Puppie Grey-
hound: hee will not ſwagger with a Barbarie Henne, if
her feathers turne backe in any ſhew of reſiſtance. Call
him vp (Drawer.)

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: Cheater, call you him? I will barre no honeſt
man my houſe, nor no Cheater: but I doe not loue ſwag-
gering; I am the worſe when one ſayes, ſwagger: Feele
Maſters, how I ſhake: looke you, I warrant you.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: So you doe, Hoſteſſe.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: Doe I? yea, in very truth doe I, if it were an Aſ-
pen Leafe: I cannot abide Swaggerers.

scene.stagedir: Enter Piſtol, and Bardolph and his Boy.

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: ’Saue you, Sir Iohn.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Welcome Ancient Piſtol. Here (Piſtol) I charge
you with a Cup of Sacke: doe you diſcharge vpon mine
Hoſteſſe.

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: I will diſcharge vpon her (Sir Iohn) with two
Bullets.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: She is Piſtoll-proofe (Sir) you ſhall hardly of-
fend her.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: Come, Ile drinke no Proofes, nor no Bullets: I
will drinke no more then will doe me good, for no mans
pleaſure, I.

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: Then to you (Miſtris Dorothie) I will charge
you.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Charge me? I ſcorne you (ſcuruie Companion)
what? you poore, baſe, raſcally, cheating, lacke-Linnen-
Mate: away you mouldie Rogue, away; I am meat for
your Maſter.

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: I know you, Miſtris Dorothie.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Away you Cut-purſe Raſcall, you ﬁlthy Bung,
away: By this Wine, Ile thruſt my Knife in your mouldie
Chappes, if you play the ſawcie Cuttle with me. Away
you Bottle-Ale Raſcall, you Basket-hilt ſtale Iugler, you.
Since when, I pray you, Sir? what, with two Points on
your ſhoulder? much.

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: I will murther your Ruﬀe, for this.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: No, good Captaine Piſtol: not heere, ſweete
Captaine.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Captaine? thou abhominable damn’d Cheater,
art thou not aſham’d to be call’d Captaine? If Captaines
were of my minde, they would trunchion you out, for ta-
king their Names vpon you, before you haue earn’d them.
You a Captaine? you ſlaue, for what? for tearing a poore
Whores Ruﬀe in a Bawdy-houſe? Hee a Captaine? hang
him Rogue, hee liues vpon mouldie ſtew’d-Pruines, and
dry’de Cakes. A Captaine? Theſe Villaines will make
the word Captaine odious: Therefore Captaines had
neede looke to it.

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: ’Pray thee goe downe, good Ancient.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Hearke thee hither, Miſtris Dol.

speech.speaker: Piﬆ.
speech.line: Not I: I tell thee what, Corporall Bardolph, I
could teare her: Ile be reueng’d on her.

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: ’Pray thee goe downe.

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: Ile ſee her damn’d ﬁrſt: to Pluto’s damn’d Lake,
to the Infernall Deepe, where Erebus and Tortures vilde
alſo. Hold Hooke and Line, ſay I: Downe: downe
Dogges, downe Fates: haue wee not Hiren here?

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: Good Captaine Peeſel be quiet, it is very late:
I beſeeke you now, aggrauate your Choler.

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: Theſe be good Humors indeede. Shall Pack-
Horſes, and hollow-pamper’d Iades of Aſia, which can-
not goe but thirtie miles a day, compare with Cæſar, and
with Caniballs, and Troian Greekes? nay, rather damne
them with King Cerberus, and let the Welkin roare: ſhall
wee fall foule for Toyes?

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: By my troth Captaine, theſe are very bitter
words.

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: Be gone, good Ancient: this will grow to a
Brawle anon.

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: Die men, like Dogges; giue Crownes like Pinnes:
Haue we not Hiren here?

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: On my word (Captaine) there’s none ſuch here.
What the good-yere, doe you thinke I would denye her?
I pray be quiet.

speech.speaker: Piﬆ.
speech.line: Then feed, and be fat (my faire Calipolis.) Come,
giue me ſome Sack, Si fortune me tormente, ſperato me con-
tente. Feare wee broad-ſides? No, let the Fiend giue ﬁre:
Giue me ſome Sack: and Sweet-heart lye thou there:
Come wee to full Points here, and are et cetera’s no-
thing?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Piﬆol, I would be quiet.

speech.speaker: Piﬆ.
speech.line: Sweet Knight, I kiſſe thy Neaﬀe: what? wee haue
ſeene the ſeuen Starres.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Thruſt him downe ſtayres, I cannot endure ſuch
a Fuſtian Raſcall.

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: Thruſt him downe ſtayres? know we not Gallo-
way Nagges?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Quoit him downe (Bardolph) like a ſhoue-groat
ſhilling: nay, if hee doe nothing but ſpeake nothing, hee
ſhall be nothing here.

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: Come, get you downe ſtayres.

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: What? ſhall wee haue Inciſion? ſhall wee em-
brew? then Death rocke me aſleepe, abridge my dolefull
dayes: why then let grieuous, gaſtly, gaping Wounds,
vntwin’d the Siſters three: Come Atropos, I ſay.

speech.speaker: Hoﬆ.
speech.line: Here’s good ſtuﬀe toward.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Giue me my Rapier, Boy.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: I prethee Iack, I prethee doe not draw.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Get you downe ſtayres.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: Here’s a goodly tumult: Ile forſweare keeping
houſe, before Ile be in theſe tirrits, and frights. So: Mur-
ther I warrant now. Alas, alas, put vp your naked Wea-
pons, put vp your naked Weapons.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: I prethee Iack be quiet, the Raſcall is gone: ah,
you whorſon little valiant Villaine, you.

speech.speaker: Hoﬆ.
speech.line: Are you not hurt i’th’ Groyne? me thought hee
made a ſhrewd Thruſt at your Belly.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Haue you turn’d him out of doores?

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: Yes Sir: the Raſcall’s drunke: you haue hurt
him (Sir) in the ſhoulder.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: A Raſcall to braue me.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Ah, you ſweet little Rogue, you: alas, poore Ape,
how thou ſweat’ſt? Come, let me wipe thy Face: Come
on, you whorſon Chops: Ah Rogue, I loue thee: Thou
art as valorous as Heƈtor of Troy, worth ﬁue of Agamem-
non, and tenne times better then the nine Worthies: ah
Villaine.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: A raſcally Slaue, I will toſſe the Rogue in a Blan-
ket.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Doe, if thou dar’ſt for thy heart: if thou doo’ſt,
Ile canuas thee betweene a paire of Sheetes.

speech.speaker: Page.
speech.line: The Muſique is come, Sir.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Let them play: play Sirs. Sit on my Knee, Dol.
A Raſcall, bragging Slaue: the Rogue ﬂed from me like
Quick-ſiluer.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: And thou followd’ſt him like a Church: thou
whorſon little tydie Bartholmew Bore-pigge, when wilt
thou leaue ﬁghting on dayes, and foyning on nights, and
begin to patch vp thine old Body for Heauen?

scene.stagedir: Enter the Prince and Poines disguis’d.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Peace (good Dol) doe not ſpeake like a Deaths-
head: doe not bid me remember mine end.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Sirrha, what humor is the Prince of?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: A good ſhallow young fellow: hee would haue
made a good Pantler, hee would haue chipp’d Bread
well.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: They ſay Poines hath a good Wit.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Hee a good Wit? hang him Baboone, his Wit is
as thicke as Tewksburie Muſtard: there is no more con-
ceit in him, then is in a Mallet.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Why doth the Prince loue him ſo then?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Becauſe their Legges are both of a bigneſſe: and
hee playes at Quoits well, and eates Conger and Fennell,
and drinkes oﬀ Candles ends for Flap-dragons, and rides
the wilde-Mare with the Boyes, and iumpes vpon Ioyn’d-
ſtooles, and ſweares with a good grace, and weares his
Boot very ſmooth, like vnto the Signe of the Legge; and
breedes no bate with telling of diſcreete ſtories: and ſuch
other Gamboll Faculties hee hath, that ſhew a weake
Minde, and an able Body, for the which the Prince admits
him; for the Prince himſelfe is ſuch another: the
weight of an hayre will turne the Scales betweene their
Haber-de-pois.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Would not this Naue of a Wheele haue his
Eares cut oﬀ?

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Let vs beat him before his Whore.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Looke, if the wither’d Elder hath not his Poll
claw’d like a Parrot.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Is it not ſtrange, that Deſire ſhould ſo many
yeeres out-liue performance?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Kiſſe me Dol.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Saturne and Venus this yeere in Coniunƈtion?
What ſayes the Almanack to that?

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: And looke whether the ﬁerie Trigon, his Man,
be not liſping to his Maſters old Tables, his Note-Booke,
his Councell-keeper?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Thou do’ſt giue me ﬂatt’ring Buſſes.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Nay truely, I kiſſe thee with a moſt conſtant
heart.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: I am olde, I am olde.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: I loue thee better, then I loue ere a ſcuruie young
Boy of them all.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: What Stuﬀe wilt thou haue a Kirtle of? I ſhall
receiue Money on Thurſday: thou ſhalt haue a Cappe
to morrow. A merrie Song, come: it growes late,
wee will to Bed. Thou wilt forget me, when I am
gone.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Thou wilt ſet me a weeping, if thou ſay’ſt ſo:
proue that euer I dreſſe my ſelfe handſome, till thy re-
turne: well, hearken the end.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Some Sack, Francis.

speech.speaker: Prin. Poin.
speech.line: Anon, anon, Sir.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Ha? a Baſtard Sonne of the Kings? And art not
thou Poines, his Brother?

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Why thou Globe of ſinfull Continents, what
a Life do’ſt thou lead?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: A better then thou: I am a Gentleman, thou art
a Drawer.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Very true, Sir: and I come to draw you out
by the Eares.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: Oh, the Lord preſerue thy good Grace: Wel-
come to London. Now Heauen bleſſe that ſweete Face
of thine: what, are you come from Wales?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Thou whorſon mad Compound of Maieſtie: by
this light Fleſh, and corrupt Blood, thou art welcome.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: How? you fat Foole, I ſcorne you.

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: My Lord, hee will driue you out of your re-
uenge, and turne all to a merryment, if you take not the
heat.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: You whorſon Candle-myne you, how vildly
did you ſpeake of me euen now, before this honeſt, ver-
tuous, ciuill Gentlewoman?

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: ’Bleſſing on your good heart, and ſo ſhee is by
my troth.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Didſt thou heare me?

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Yes: and you knew me, as you did when you
ranne away by Gads-hill: you knew I was at your back,
and ſpoke it on purpoſe, to trie my patience.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: No, no, no: not ſo: I did not thinke, thou waſt
within hearing.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: I ſhall driue you then to confeſſe the wilfull
abuſe, and then I know how to handle you.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: No abuſe (Hall) on mine Honor, no abuſe.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Not to diſprayſe me? and call me Pantler, and
Bread-chopper, and I know not what?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: No abuſe (Hal.)

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: No abuſe?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: No abuſe (Ned) in the World: honeſt Ned none.
I diſprays’d him before the Wicked, that the Wicked
might not fall in loue with him: In which doing, I haue
done the part of a carefull Friend, and a true Subieƈt, and
thy Father is to giue me thankes for it. No abuſe (Hal:)
none (Ned) none; no Boyes, none.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: See now whether pure Feare, and entire Cow-
ardiſe, doth not make thee wrong this vertuous Gentle-
woman, to cloſe with vs? Is ſhee of the Wicked? Is thine
Hoſteſſe heere, of the Wicked? Or is the Boy of the
Wicked? Or honeſt Bardolph (whoſe Zeale burnes in his
Noſe) of the Wicked?

speech.speaker: Poin.
speech.line: Anſwere thou dead Elme, anſwere.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: The Fiend hath prickt downe Bardolph irrecoue-
rable, and his Face is Lucifers Priuy-Kitchin, where hee
doth nothing but roſt Mault-Wormes: for the Boy,
there is a good Angell about him, but the Deuill out-
bids him too.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: For the Women?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: For one of them, ſhee is in Hell alreadie, and
burnes poore Soules: for the other, I owe her Mo-
ney; and whether ſhee bee damn’d for that, I know
not.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: No, I warrant you.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: No, I thinke thou art not: I thinke thou art quit
for that. Marry, there is another Indiƈtment vpon thee,
for ſuﬀering ﬂeſh to bee eaten in thy houſe, contrary to
the Law, for the which I thinke thou wilt howle.

speech.speaker: Hoﬆ.
speech.line: All Viƈtuallers doe ſo: What is a Ioynt of
Mutton, or two, in a whole Lent?

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: You, Gentlewoman.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: What ſayes your Grace?

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: His Grace ſayes that, which his ﬂeſh rebells
againſt.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: Who knocks ſo lowd at doore? Looke to the
doore there, Francis?

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Peto, how now? what newes?

speech.speaker: Peto.
speech.line: The King, your Father, is at Weſtminſter,
And there are twentie weake and wearied Poſtes,
Come from the North: and as I came along,
I met, and ouer-tooke a dozen Captaines,
Bare-headed, ſweating, knocking at the Tauernes,
And asking euery one for Sir Iohn Falſtaﬀe.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: By Heauen (Poines) I feele me much to blame,
So idly to prophane the precious time,
When Tempeſt of Commotion, like the South,
Borne with black Vapour, doth begin to melt,
And drop vpon our bare vnarmed heads.
Giue me my Sword, and Cloake:
Falſtaﬀe, good night.

speech.speaker: Falﬆ.
speech.line: Now comes in the ſweeteſt Morſell of the
night, and wee muſt hence, and leaue it vnpickt. More
knocking at the doore? How now? what’s the mat-
ter?

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: You muſt away to Court, Sir, preſently,
A dozen Captaines ſtay at doore for you.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Pay the Muſitians, Sirrha: farewell Hoſteſſe,
farewell Dol. You ſee (my good Wenches) how men of
Merit are ſought after: the vndeſeruer may ſleepe, when
the man of Aƈtion is call’d on. Farewell good Wenches:
if I be not ſent away poſte, I will ſee you againe, ere I
goe.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: I cannot ſpeake: if my heart bee not readie
to burſt— Well (ſweete Iacke) haue a care of thy
ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Farewell, farewell.

speech.speaker: Hoﬆ.
speech.line: Well, fare thee well: I haue knowne thee
theſe twentie nine yeeres, come Peſcod-time: but an
honeſter, and truer-hearted man — Well, fare thee
well.

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: Miſtris Teare-ſheet.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: Bid Miſtris Teare-ſheet come to my Maſter.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: Oh runne Dol, runne: runne, good Dol.

scene.stagedir: Enter the King, with a Page.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Goe, call the Earles of Surrey, and of Warwick:
But ere they come, bid them ore-reade theſe Letters,
And well conſider of them: make good ſpeed. Exit.
How many thouſand of my pooreſt Subieƈts
Are at this howre aſleepe? O Sleepe, O gentle Sleepe,
Natures ſoft Nurſe, how haue I frighted thee,
That thou no more wilt weigh my eye-lids downe,
And ſteepe my Sences in Forgetfulneſſe?
Why rather (Sleepe) lyeſt thou in ſmoakie Cribs,
Vpon vneaſie Pallads ſtretching thee,
And huiſht with buſſing Night, ﬂyes to thy ſlumber,
Then in the perfum’d Chambers of the Great?
Vnder the Canopies of coſtly State,
And lull’d with ſounds of ſweeteſt Melodie?
O thou dull God, why lyeſt thou with the vilde,
In loathſome Beds, and leau’ſt the Kingly Couch,
A Watch-caſe, or a common Larum-Bell?
Wilt thou, vpon the high and giddie Maſt,
Seale vp the Ship-boyes Eyes, and rock his Braines,
In Cradle of the rude imperious Surge,
And in the viſitation of the Windes,
Who take the Ruﬃan Billowes by the top,
Curling their monſtrous heads, and hanging them
With deaﬀ’ning Clamors in the ſlipp’ry Clouds,
That with the hurley, Death it ſelfe awakes?
Canſt thou (O partiall Sleepe) giue thy Repoſe
To the wet Sea-Boy, in an houre ſo rude:
And in the calmeſt, and moſt ſtilleſt Night,
With all appliances, and meanes to boote,
Deny it to a King? Then happy Lowe, lye downe,
Vneaſie lyes the Head, that weares a Crowne.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Many good-morrowes to your Maieſtie.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Is it good-morrow, Lords?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: ’Tis One a Clock, and paſt.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Why then good-morrow to you all (my Lords:)
Haue you read o’re the Letters that I ſent you?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: We haue (my Liege.)

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Then you perceiue the Body of our Kingdome,
How foule it is: what ranke Diſeaſes grow,
And with what danger, neere the Heart of it?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: It is but as a Body, yet diſtemper’d,
Which to his former ſtrength may be reſtor’d,
With good aduice, and little Medicine:
My Lord Northumberland will ſoone be cool’d.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Oh Heauen, that one might read the Book of Fate,
And ſee the reuolution of the Times
Make Mountaines leuell, and the Continent
(Wearie of ſolide ﬁrmeneſſe) melt it ſelfe
Into the Sea: and other Times, to ſee
The beachie Girdle of the Ocean
Too wide for Neptunes hippes; how Chances mocks
And Changes ﬁll the Cuppe of Alteration
With diuers Liquors. ’Tis not tenne yeeres gone,
Since Richard, and Northumberland, great friends,
Did feaſt together; and in two yeeres after,
Were they at Warres. It is but eight yeeres ſince,
This Percie was the man, neereſt my Soule,
Who, like a Brother, toyl’d in my Aﬀaires,
And layd his Loue and Life vnder my foot:
Yea, for my ſake, euen to the eyes of Richard
Gaue him deﬁance. But which of you was by
(You Couſin Neuil, as I may remember)
When Richard, with his Eye, brim-full of Teares,
(Then check’d, and rated by Northumberland)
Did ſpeake theſe words (now prou’d a Prophecie:)
Northumberland, thou Ladder, by the which
My Couſin Bullingbrooke aſcends my Throne:
(Though then, Heauen knowes, I had no ſuch intent,
But that neceſſitie ſo bow’d the State,
That I and Greatneſſe were compell’d to kiſſe:)
The Time ſhall come (thus did hee follow it)
The Time will come, that foule Sinne gathering head,
Shall breake into Corruption: ſo went on,
Fore-telling this ſame Times Condition,
And the diuiſion of our Amitie.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: There is a Hiſtorie in all mens Liues,
Figuring the nature of the Times deceas’d:
The which obſeru’d, a man may prophecie
With a neere ayme, of the maine chance of things,
As yet not come to Life, which in their Seedes
And weake beginnings lye entreaſured:
Such things become the Hatch and Brood of Time;
And by the neceſſarie forme of this,
King Richard might create a perfeƈt gueſſe,
That great Northumberland, then falſe to him,
Would of that Seed, grow to a greater falſeneſſe,
Which ſhould not ﬁnde a ground to roote vpon,
Vnleſſe on you.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Are theſe things then Neceſſities?
Then let vs meete them like Neceſſities;
And that ſame word, euen now cryes out on vs:
They ſay, the Biſhop and Northumberland
Are ﬁftie thouſand ſtrong.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: It cannot be (my Lord:)
Rumor doth double, like the Voice, and Eccho,
The numbers of the feared. Pleaſe it your Grace
To goe to bed, vpon my Life (my Lord)
The Pow’rs that you alreadie haue ſent forth,
Shall bring this Prize in very eaſily.
To comfort you the more, I haue receiu’d
A certaine inſtance, that Glendour is dead.
