Your Maieſtie hath beene this fort-night ill,
And theſe vnſeaſon’d howres perforce muſt adde
Vnto your Sickneſſe.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I will take your counſaile:
And were theſe inward Warres once out of hand,
Wee would (deare Lords) vnto the Holy-Land.

scene.stagedir: Enter Shallow and Silence: with Mouldie, Shadow, Wart, Feeble, Bull-calfe.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Come-on, come-on, come-on: giue mee your
Hand, Sir; giue mee your Hand, Sir: an early ſtirrer, by
the Rood. And how doth my good Couſin Silence?

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Good-morrow, good Couſin Shallow.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: And how doth my Couſin, your Bed-fellow?
and your faireſt Daughter, and mine, my God-Daughter
Ellen?

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Alas, a blacke Ouzell (Couſin Shallow.)

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: By yea and nay, Sir. I dare ſay my Couſin William
is become a good Scholler? hee is at Oxford ſtill, is hee
not?

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Indeede Sir, to my coſt.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Hee muſt then to the Innes of Court ſhortly: I
was once of Clements Inne; where (I thinke) they will
talke of mad Shallow yet.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: You were call’d luſtie Shallow then (Couſin.)

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: I was call’d any thing: and I would haue done
any thing indeede too, and roundly too. There was I, and
little Iohn Doit of Staﬀordſhire, and blacke George Bare,
and Francis Pick-bone, and Will Squele a Cot-ſal-man, you
had not foure ſuch Swindge-bucklers in all the Innes of
Court againe: And I may ſay to you, wee knew where
the Bona-Roba’s were, and had the beſt of them all at
commandement. Then was Iacke Falſtaﬀe (now Sir Iohn)
a Boy, and Page to Thomas Mowbray, Duke of Nor-
folke.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: This Sir Iohn (Couſin) that comes hither anon a-
bout Souldiers?

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: The ſame Sir Iohn, the very ſame: I ſaw him
breake Scoggan’s Head at the Court-Gate, when hee was
a Crack, not thus high: and the very ſame day did I ﬁght
with one Sampſon Stock-ﬁſh, a Fruiterer, behinde Greyes-
Inne. Oh the mad dayes that I haue ſpent! and to ſee
how many of mine olde Acquaintance are dead?

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Wee ſhall all follow (Couſin.)

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Certaine: ’tis certaine: very ſure, very ſure:
Death is certaine to all, all ſhall dye. How a good Yoke
of Bullocks at Stamford Fayre?

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Truly Couſin, I was not there.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Death is certaine. Is old Double of your Towne
liuing yet?

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Dead, Sir.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Dead? See, ſee: hee drew a good Bow: and
dead? hee ſhot a ﬁne ſhoote. Iohn of Gaunt loued
him well, and betted much Money on his head. Dead?
hee would haue clapt in the Clowt at Twelue-ſcore, and
carryed you a fore-hand Shaft at foureteene, and foure-
teene and a halfe, that it would haue done a mans heart
good to ſee. How a ſcore of Ewes now?

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Thereafter as they be: a ſcore of good Ewes
may be worth tenne pounds.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: And is olde Double dead?

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Heere come two of Sir Iohn Falſtaﬀes Men (as I
thinke.)

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Good-morrow, honeſt Gentlemen.

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: I beſeech you, which is Iuſtice Shallow?

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: I am Robert Shallow (Sir) a poore Eſquire of this
Countie, and one of the Kings Iuſtices of the Peace:
What is your good pleaſure with me?

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: My Captaine (Sir) commends him to you:
my Captaine, Sir Iohn Falſtaﬀe: a tall Gentleman, and a
moſt gallant Leader.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Hee greetes me well: (Sir) I knew him a
good Back-Sword-man. How doth the good Knight?
may I aske, how my Lady his Wife doth?

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: Sir, pardon: a Souldier is better accommoda-
ted, then with a Wife.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: It is well ſaid, Sir; and it is well ſaid, indeede,
too: Better accommodated? it is good, yea indeede is
it: good phraſes are ſurely, and euery where very com-
mendable. Accommodated, it comes of Accommodo:
very good, a good Phraſe.

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: Pardon, Sir, I haue heard the word. Phraſe
call you it? by this Day, I know not the Phraſe: but
I will maintaine the Word with my Sword, to bee a
Souldier-like Word, and a Word of exceeding good
Command. Accommodated: that is, when a man is
(as they ſay) accommodated: or, when a man is, being
whereby he thought to be accommodated, which is an
excellent thing.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: It is very iuſt: Looke, heere comes good Sir
Iohn. Giue me your hand, giue me your Worſhips good
hand: Truſt me, you looke well: and beare your yeares
very well. Welcome, good Sir Iohn.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: I am glad to ſee you well, good M. Robert Shal-
low: Maſter Sure-card as I thinke?

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: No ſir Iohn, it is my Coſin Silence: in Commiſſi-
on with mee.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Good M. Silence, it well beﬁts you ſhould be of
the peace.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Your good Worſhip is welcome.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Fye, this is hot weather (Gentlemen) haue you
prouided me heere halfe a dozen of ſuﬃcient men?

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Marry haue we ſir: Will you ſit?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Let me ſee them, I beſeech you.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Where’s the Roll? Where’s the Roll? Where’s
the Roll? Let me ſee, let me ſee, let me ſee: ſo, ſo, ſo, ſo:
yea marry Sir. Raphe Mouldie: let them appeare as I call:
let them do ſo, let them do ſo: Let mee ſee, Where is
Mouldie?

speech.speaker: Moul.
speech.line: Heere, if it pleaſe you.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: What thinke you (Sir Iohn) a good limb’d fel-
low: yong, ſtrong, and of good friends.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Is thy name Mouldie?

speech.speaker: Moul.
speech.line: Yea, if it pleaſe you.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: ’Tis the more time thou wert vs’d.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Ha, ha, ha, moſt excellent. Things that are moul-
die, lacke vſe: very ſingular good. Well ſaide Sir Iohn,
very well ſaid.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Pricke him.

speech.speaker: Moul.
speech.line: I was prickt well enough before, if you could
haue let me alone: my old Dame will be vndone now, for
one to doe her Husbandry, and her Drudgery; you need
not to haue prickt me, there are other men ﬁtter to goe
out, then I.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Go too: peace Mouldie, you ſhall goe. Mouldie,
it is time you were ſpent.

speech.speaker: Moul.
speech.line: Spent?

speech.speaker: Shallow.
speech.line: Peace, fellow, peace; ſtand aſide: Know you
where you are? For the other ſir Iohn: Let me ſee: Simon
Shadow.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: I marry, let me haue him to ſit vnder: he’s like to
be a cold ſouldier.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Where’s Shadow?

speech.speaker: Shad.
speech.line: Heere ſir.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Shadow, whoſe ſonne art thou?

speech.speaker: Shad.
speech.line: My Mothers ſonne, Sir.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Thy Mothers ſonne: like enough, and thy Fa-
thers ſhadow: ſo the ſonne of the Female, is the ſhadow
of the Male: it is often ſo indeede, but not of the Fathers
ſubſtance.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Do you like him, ſir Iohn?

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Shadow will ſerue for Summer: pricke him: For
wee haue a number of ſhadowes to ﬁll vppe the Muſter-
Booke.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Thomas Wart?

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Where’s he?

speech.speaker: Wart.
speech.line: Heere ſir.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Is thy name Wart?

speech.speaker: Wart.
speech.line: Yea ſir.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Thou art a very ragged Wart.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Shall I pricke him downe,
Sir Iohn?

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: It were ſuperﬂuous: for his apparrel is built vp-
on his backe, and the whole frame ſtands vpon pins: prick
him no more.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Ha, ha, ha, you can do it ſir: you can doe it: I
commend you well.
Francis Feeble.

speech.speaker: Feeble.
speech.line: Heere ſir.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: What Trade art thou Feeble?

speech.speaker: Feeble.
speech.line: A Womans Taylor ſir.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Shall I pricke him, ſir?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: You may:
But if he had beene a mans Taylor, he would haue prick’d
you. Wilt thou make as many holes in an enemies Bat-
taile, as thou haſt done in a Womans petticote?

speech.speaker: Feeble.
speech.line: I will doe my good will ſir, you can haue no
more.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Well ſaid, good Womans Tailour: Well ſayde
Couragious Feeble: thou wilt bee as valiant as the wrath-
full Doue, or moſt magnanimous Mouſe. Pricke the wo-
mans Taylour well Maſter Shallow, deepe Maiſter Shal-
low.

speech.speaker: Feeble.
speech.line: I would Wart might haue gone ſir.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: I would thou wert a mans Tailor, that ӳ might’ſt
mend him, and make him ﬁt to goe. I cannot put him to
a priuate ſouldier, that is the Leader of ſo many thou-
ſands. Let that ſuﬃce, moſt Forcible Feeble.

speech.speaker: Feeble.
speech.line: It ſhall ſuﬃce.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: I am bound to thee, reuerend Feeble. Who is
the next?

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Peter Bulcalfe of the Greene.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Yea marry, let vs ſee Bulcalfe.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Heere ſir.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Truſt me, a likely Fellow. Come, pricke me Bul-
calfe till he roare againe.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Oh, good my Lord Captaine.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: What? do’ſt thou roare before th’art prickt.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Oh ſir, I am a diſeaſed man.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: What diſeaſe haſt thou?

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: A whorſon cold ſir, a cough ſir, which I caught
with Ringing in the Kings aﬀayres, vpon his Coronation
day, ſir.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Come, thou ſhalt go to the Warres in a Gowne:
we will haue away thy Cold, and I will take ſuch order,
that thy friends ſhall ring for thee. Is heere all?

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: There is two more called then your number:
you muſt haue but foure heere ſir, and ſo I pray you go in
with me to dinner.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Come, I will goe drinke with you, but I cannot
tarry dinner. I am glad to ſee you in good troth, Maſter
Shallow.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: O ſir Iohn, doe you remember ſince wee lay all
night in the Winde-mill, in S. Georges Field.

speech.speaker: Falſtaﬀe.
speech.line: No more of that good Maſter Shallow: No
more of that.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Ha? it was a merry night. And is Iane Night-
worke aliue?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: She liues, M. Shallow.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: She neuer could away with me.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Neuer, neuer: ſhe would alwayes ſay ſhee could
not abide M. Shallow.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: I could anger her to the heart: ſhee was then a
Bona-Roba. Doth ſhe hold her owne well.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Old, old, M. Shallow.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Nay, ſhe muſt be old, ſhe cannot chooſe but be
old: certaine ſhee’s old: and had Robin Night-worke, by
old Night-worke, before I came to Clements Inne.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: That’s ﬁftie ﬁue yeeres agoe.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Hah, Couſin Silence, that thou hadſt ſeene that,
that this Knight and I haue ſeene: hah, Sir Iohn, ſaid I
well?

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Wee haue heard the Chymes at mid-night, Ma-
ſter Shallow.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: That wee haue, that wee haue; in faith, Sir Iohn,
wee haue: our watch-word was, Hem-Boyes. Come,
let’s to Dinner; come, let’s to Dinner: Oh the dayes that
wee haue ſeene. Come, come.

speech.speaker: Bul.
speech.line: Good Maſter Corporate Bardolph, ſtand my
friend, and heere is foure Harry tenne ſhillings in French
Crownes for you: in very truth, ſir, I had as lief be hang’d
ſir, as goe: and yet, for mine owne part, ſir, I do not care;
but rather, becauſe I am vnwilling, and for mine owne
part, haue a deſire to ſtay with my friends: elſe, ſir, I did
not care, for mine owne part, ſo much.

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: Go-too: ſtand aſide.

speech.speaker: Mould.
speech.line: And good Maſter Corporall Captaine, for my
old Dames ſake, ſtand my friend: ſhee hath no body to
doe any thing about her, when I am gone: and ſhe is old,
and cannot helpe her ſelfe: you ſhall haue fortie, ſir.

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: Go-too: ſtand aſide.

speech.speaker: Feeble.
speech.line: I care not, a man can die but once: wee owe a
death. I will neuer beare a baſe minde: if it be my deſti-
nie, ſo: if it be not, ſo: no man is too good to ſerue his
Prince: and let it goe which way it will, he that dies this
yeere, is quit for the next.

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: Well ſaid, thou art a good fellow.

speech.speaker: Feeble.
speech.line: Nay, I will beare no baſe minde.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Come ſir, which men ſhall I haue?

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Foure of which you pleaſe.

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: Sir, a word with you: I haue three pound, to
free Mouldie and Bull-calfe.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Go-too: well.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Come, ſir Iohn, which foure will you haue?

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Doe you chuſe for me.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Marry then, Mouldie, Bull-calfe, Feeble, and
Shadow.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Mouldie, and Bull-calfe: for you Mouldie, ſtay
at home, till you are paſt ſeruice: and for your part, Bull-
calfe, grow till you come vnto it: I will none of you.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Sir Iohn, Sir Iohn, doe not your ſelfe wrong, they
are your likelyeſt men, and I would haue you ſeru’d with
the beſt.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Will you tell me (Maſter Shallow) how to chuſe
a man? Care I for the Limbe, the Thewes, the ſtature,
bulke, and bigge aſſemblance of a man? giue mee the
ſpirit (Maſter Shallow.) Where’s Wart? you ſee what
a ragged appearance it is: hee ſhall charge you, and
diſcharge you, with the motion of a Pewterers Ham-
mer: come oﬀ, and on, ſwifter then hee that gibbets on
the Brewers Bucket. And this ſame halfe-fac’d fellow,
Shadow, giue me this man: hee preſents no marke to the
Enemie, the foe-man may with as great ayme leuell at
the edge of a Pen-knife: and for a Retrait, how ſwiftly
will this Feeble, the Womans Taylor, runne oﬀ. O, giue
me the ſpare men, and ſpare me the great ones. Put me a
Calyuer into Warts hand, Bardolph.

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: Hold Wart, Trauerſe: thus, thus, thus.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Come, manage me your Calyuer: ſo: very well,
go-too, very good, exceeding good. O, giue me alwayes
a little, leane, old, chopt, bald Shot. Well ſaid Wart, thou
art a good Scab: hold, there is a Teſter for thee.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Hee is not his Crafts-maſter, hee doth not doe
it right. I remember at Mile-end-Greene, when I lay
at Clements Inne, I was then Sir Dagonet in Arthurs
Show: there was a little quiuer fellow, and hee would
manage you his Peece thus: and hee would about,
and about, and come you in, and come you in: Rah,
tah, tah, would hee ſay, Bownce would hee ſay, and
away againe would hee goe, and againe would he come:
I ſhall neuer ſee ſuch a fellow.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Theſe fellowes will doe well, Maſter Shallow.
Farewell Maſter Silence, I will not vſe many wordes with
you: fare you well, Gentlemen both: I thanke you:
I muſt a dozen mile to night. Bardolph, giue the Souldiers
Coates.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Sir Iohn, Heauen bleſſe you, and proſper your
Aﬀaires, and ſend vs Peace. As you returne, viſit
my houſe. Let our old acquaintance be renewed: per-
aduenture I will with you to the Court.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: I would you would, Maſter Shallow.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Go-too: I haue ſpoke at a word. Fare you
well.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Fare you well, gentle Gentlemen. On Bar-
dolph, leade the men away. As I returne, I will fetch oﬀ
theſe Iuſtices: I doe ſee the bottome of Iuſtice Shal-
low. How ſubieƈt wee old men are to this vice of Ly-
ing? This ſame ſtaru’d Iuſtice hath done nothing but
prate to me of the wildeneſſe of his Youth, and the
Feates hee hath done about Turnball-ſtreet, and euery
third word a Lye, duer pay’d to the hearer, then the
Turkes Tribute. I doe remember him at Clements Inne,
like a man made after Supper, of a Cheeſe-paring. When
hee was naked, hee was, for all the world, like a forked
Radiſh, with a Head fantaſtically caru’d vpon it with a
Knife. Hee was ſo forlorne, that his Dimenſions (to
any thicke ſight) were inuincible. Hee was the very
Genius of Famine: hee came euer in the rere-ward of
the Faſhion: And now is this Vices Dagger become a
Squire, and talkes as familiarly of Iohn of Gaunt, as if
hee had beene ſworne Brother to him: and Ile be ſworne
hee neuer ſaw him but once in the Tilt-yard, and then he
burſt his Head, for crowding among the Marſhals men.
I ſaw it, and told Iohn of Gaunt, hee beat his owne
Name, for you might haue truſs’d him and all his Ap-
parrell into an Eele-skinne: the Caſe of a Treble Hoe-
boy was a Manſion for him: a Court: and now hath
hee Land, and Beeues. Well, I will be acquainted with
him, if I returne: and it ſhall goe hard, but I will make
him a Philoſophers two Stones to me. If the young
Dace be a Bayt for the old Pike, I ſee no reaſon, in the
Law of Nature, but I may ſnap at him. Let time ſhape,
and there an end.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Arch-biſhop, Mowbray, Haﬆings, Weﬆmerland, Coleuile.

speech.speaker: Biſh.
speech.line: What is this Forreſt call’d?

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: ’Tis Gaultree Forreſt, and’t ſhall pleaſe your
Grace.

speech.speaker: Biſh.
speech.line: Here ſtand (my Lords) and ſend diſcouerers forth,
To know the numbers of our Enemies.

speech.speaker: Haﬆ.
speech.line: Wee haue ſent forth alreadie.

speech.speaker: Biſh.
speech.line: ’Tis well done.
My Friends, and Brethren (in theſe great Aﬀaires)
I muſt acquaint you, that I haue receiu’d
New-dated Letters from Northumberland:
Their cold intent, tenure, and ſubſtance thus.
Here doth hee wiſh his Perſon, with ſuch Powers
As might hold ſortance with his Qualitie,
The which hee could not leuie: whereupon
Hee is retyr’d, to ripe his growing Fortunes,
To Scotland; and concludes in heartie prayers,
That your Attempts may ouer-liue the hazard,
And fearefull meeting of their Oppoſite.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: Thus do the hopes we haue in him, touch ground,
And daſh themſelues to pieces.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: Now? what newes?

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Weſt of this Forreſt, ſcarcely oﬀ a mile,
In goodly forme, comes on the Enemie:
And by the ground they hide, I iudge their number
Vpon, or neere, the rate of thirtie thouſand.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: The iuſt proportion that we gaue them out.
Let vs ſway-on, and face them in the ﬁeld.

speech.speaker: Biſh.
speech.line: What well-appointed Leader fronts vs here?

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: I thinke it is my Lord of Weſtmerland.

speech.speaker: Weſt.
speech.line: Health, and faire greeting from our Generall,
The Prince, Lord Iohn, and Duke of Lancaſter.

speech.speaker: Biſh.
speech.line: Say on (my Lord of Weſtmerland) in peace:
What doth concerne your comming?

speech.speaker: Weﬆ.
speech.line: Then (my Lord)
Vnto your Grace doe I in chiefe addreſſe
The ſubſtance of my Speech. If that Rebellion
Came like it ſelfe, in baſe and abieƈt Routs,
Led on by bloodie Youth, guarded with Rage,
And countenanc’d by Boyes, and Beggerie:
I ſay, if damn’d Commotion ſo appeare,
In his true, natiue, and moſt proper ſhape,
You (Reuerend Father, and theſe Noble Lords)
Had not beene here, to dreſſe the ougly forme
Of baſe, and bloodie Inſurreƈtion,
With your faire Honors. You, Lord Arch-biſhop,
Whoſe Sea is by a Ciuill Peace maintain’d,
Whoſe Beard, the Siluer Hand of Peace hath touch’d,
Whoſe Learning, and good Letters, Peace hath tutor’d,
Whoſe white Inueſtments ﬁgure Innocence,
The Doue, and very bleſſed Spirit of Peace.
Wherefore doe you ſo ill tranſlate your ſelfe,
Out of the Speech of Peace, that beares ſuch grace,
Into the harſh and boyſtrous Tongue of Warre?
Turning your Bookes to Graues, your Inke to Blood,
Your Pennes to Launces, and your Tongue diuine
To a lowd Trumpet, and a Point of Warre.

speech.speaker: Biſh.
speech.line: Wherefore doe I this? ſo the Queſtion ſtands.
Briefely to this end: Wee are all diſeas’d,
And with our ſurfetting, and wanton howres,
Haue brought our ſelues into a burning Feuer,
And wee muſt bleede for it: of which Diſeaſe,
Our late King Richard (being infeƈted) dy’d.
But (my moſt Noble Lord of Weſtmerland)
I take not on me here as a Phyſician,
Nor doe I, as an Enemie to Peace,
Troope in the Throngs of Militarie men:
But rather ſhew a while like fearefull Warre,
To dyet ranke Mindes, ſicke of happineſſe,
And purge th’ obſtruƈtions, which begin to ſtop
Our very Veines of Life: heare me more plainely.
I haue in equall ballance iuſtly weigh’d,
What wrongs our Arms may do, what wrongs we ſuﬀer,
And ﬁnde our Griefes heauier then our Oﬀences.
Wee ſee which way the ſtreame of Time doth runne,
And are enforc’d from our moſt quiet there,
By the rough Torrent of Occaſion,
And haue the ſummarie of all our Griefes
(When time ſhall ſerue) to ſhew in Articles;
Which long ere this, wee oﬀer’d to the King,
And might, by no Suit, gayne our Audience:
When wee are wrong’d, and would vnfold our Griefes,
Wee are deny’d acceſſe vnto his Perſon,
Euen by thoſe men, that moſt haue done vs wrong.
The dangers of the dayes but newly gone,
Whoſe memorie is written on the Earth
With yet appearing blood; and the examples
Of euery Minutes inſtance (preſent now)
Hath put vs in theſe ill-beſeeming Armes:
Not to breake Peace, or any Branch of it,
But to eſtabliſh here a Peace indeede,
Concurring both in Name and Qualitie.

speech.speaker: Weſt.
speech.line: When euer yet was your Appeale deny’d?
Wherein haue you beene galled by the King?
What Peere hath beene ſuborn’d, to grate on you,
That you ſhould ſeale this lawleſſe bloody Booke
Of forg’d Rebellion, with a Seale diuine?

speech.speaker: Biſh.
speech.line: My Brother generall, the Common-wealth,
I make my Quarrell, in particular.

speech.speaker: Weſt.
speech.line: There is no neede of any ſuch redreſſe:
Or if there were, it not belongs to you.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: Why not to him in part, and to vs all,
That feele the bruizes of the dayes before,
And ſuﬀer the Condition of theſe Times
To lay a heauie and vnequall Hand vpon our Honors?

speech.speaker: Weſt.
speech.line: O my good Lord Mowbray,
Conſtrue the Times to their Neceſſities,
And you ſhall ſay (indeede) it is the Time,
And not the King, that doth you iniuries.
Yet for your part, it not appeares to me,
Either from the King, or in the preſent Time,
That you ſhould haue an ynch of any ground
To build a Griefe on: were you not reſtor’d
To all the Duke of Norfolkes Seignories,
Your Noble, and right well-remembred Fathers?

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: What thing, in Honor, had my Father loſt,
That need to be reuiu’d, and breath’d in me?
The King that lou’d him, as the State ſtood then,
Was forc’d, perforce compell’d to baniſh him:
And then, that Henry Bullingbrooke and hee
Being mounted, and both rowſed in their Seates,
Their neighing Courſers daring of the Spurre,
Their armed Staues in charge, their Beauers downe,
Their eyes of ﬁre, ſparkling through ſights of Steele,
And the lowd Trumpet blowing them together:
Then, then, when there was nothing could haue ſtay’d
My Father from the Breaſt of Bullingbrooke;
O, when the King did throw his Warder downe,
(His owne Life hung vpon the Staﬀe hee threw)
Then threw hee downe himſelfe, and all their Liues,
That by Indiƈtment, and by dint of Sword,
Haue ſince miſ-carryed vnder Bullingbrooke.

speech.speaker: Weſt.
speech.line: You ſpeak (Lord Mowbray) now you know not what.
The Earle of Hereford was reputed then
In England the moſt valiant Gentleman.
Who knowes, on whom Fortune would then haue ſmil’d?
But if your Father had beene Viƈtor there,
Hee ne’re had borne it out of Couentry.
For all the Countrey, in a generall voyce,
Cry’d hate vpon him: and all their prayers, and loue,
Were ſet on Herford, whom they doted on,
And bleſs’d, and grac’d, and did more then the King.
But this is meere digreſſion from my purpoſe.
Here come I from our Princely Generall,
To know your Griefes; to tell you, from his Grace,
That hee will giue you Audience: and wherein
It ſhall appeare, that your demands are iuſt,
You ſhall enioy them, euery thing ſet oﬀ,
That might ſo much as thinke you Enemies.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: But hee hath forc’d vs to compell this Oﬀer,
And it proceedes from Pollicy, not Loue.

speech.speaker: Weſt.
speech.line: Mowbray, you ouer-weene to take it ſo:
This Oﬀer comes from Mercy, not from Feare.
For loe, within a Ken our Army lyes,
Vpon mine Honor, all too conﬁdent
To giue admittance to a thought of feare.
Our Battaile is more full of Names then yours,
Our Men more perfeƈt in the vſe of Armes,
Our Armor all as ſtrong, our Cauſe the beſt;
Then Reaſon will, our hearts ſhould be as good.
Say you not then, our Oﬀer is compell’d.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: Well, by my will, wee ſhall admit no Parley.

speech.speaker: Weﬆ.
speech.line: That argues but the ſhame of your oﬀence:
A rotten Caſe abides no handling.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: Hath the Prince Iohn a full Commiſſion,
In very ample vertue of his Father,
To heare, and abſolutely to determine
Of what Conditions wee ſhall ſtand vpon?

speech.speaker: Weſt.
speech.line: That is intended in the Generals Name:
I muſe you make ſo ſlight a Queſtion.

speech.speaker: Biſh.
speech.line: Then take (my Lord of Weſtmerland) this Schedule,
For this containes our generall Grieuances:
Each ſeuerall Article herein redreſs’d,
All members of our Cauſe, both here, and hence,
That are inſinewed to this Aƈtion,
Acquitted by a true ſubſtantiall forme,
And preſent execution of our wills,
To vs, and to our purpoſes conﬁn’d,
Wee come within our awfull Banks againe,
And knit our Powers to the Arme of Peace.

speech.speaker: Weſt.
speech.line: This will I ſhew the Generall. Pleaſe you Lords,
In ſight of both our Battailes, wee may meete
At either end in peace: which Heauen ſo frame,
Or to the place of diﬀerence call the Swords,
Which muſt decide it.

speech.speaker: Biſh.
speech.line: My Lord, wee will doe ſo.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: There is a thing within my Boſome tells me,
That no Conditions of our Peace can ſtand.

speech.speaker: Haﬆ.
speech.line: Feare you not, that if wee can make our Peace
Vpon ſuch large termes, and ſo abſolute,
As our Conditions ſhall conſiſt vpon,
Our Peace ſhall ſtand as ﬁrme as Rockie Mountaines.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: I, but our valuation ſhall be ſuch,
That euery ſlight, and falſe-deriued Cauſe,
Yea, euery idle, nice, and wanton Reaſon,
Shall, to the King, taſte of this Aƈtion:
That were our Royall faiths, Martyrs in Loue,
Wee ſhall be winnowed with ſo rough a winde,
That euen our Corne ſhall ſeeme as light as Chaﬀe,
And good from bad ﬁnde no partition.

speech.speaker: Biſh.
speech.line: No, no (my Lord) note this: the King is wearie
Of daintie, and ſuch picking Grieuances:
For hee hath found, to end one doubt by Death,
Reuiues two greater in the Heires of Life.
And therefore will hee wipe his Tables cleane,
And keepe no Tell-tale to his Memorie,
That may repeat, and Hiſtorie his loſſe,
To new remembrance. For full well hee knowes,
Hee cannot ſo preciſely weede this Land,
As his miſ-doubts preſent occaſion:
His foes are ſo en-rooted with his friends,
That plucking to vnﬁxe an Enemie,
Hee doth vnfaſten ſo, and ſhake a friend.
So that this Land, like an oﬀenſiue wife,
That hath enrag’d him on, to oﬀer ſtrokes,
As he is ſtriking, holds his Infant vp,
And hangs reſolu’d Correƈtion in the Arme,
That was vprear’d to execution.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: Beſides, the King hath waſted all his Rods,
On late Oﬀenders, that he now doth lacke
The very Inſtruments of Chaſticement:
So that his power, like to a Fangleſſe Lion
May oﬀer, but not hold.

speech.speaker: Biſh.
speech.line: ’Tis very true:
And therefore be aſſur’d (my good Lord Marſhal)
If we do now make our attonement well,
Our Peace, will (like a broken Limbe vnited)
Grow ſtronger, for the breaking.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: Be it ſo:
Heere is return’d my Lord of Weſtmerland.

speech.speaker: Weſt.
speech.line: The Prince is here at hand: pleaſeth your Lordſhip
To meet his Grace, iuſt diſtance ’tweene our Armies?

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: Your Grace of Yorke, in heauen’s name then
forward.

speech.speaker: Biſh.
speech.line: Before, and greet his Grace (my Lord) we come.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: You are wel encountred here (my coſin Mowbray)
Good day to you, gentle Lord Archbiſhop,
And ſo to you Lord Haſtings, and to all.
My Lord of Yorke, it better ſhew’d with you,
When that your Flocke (aſſembled by the Bell)
Encircled you, to heare with reuerence
Your expoſition on the holy Text,
Then now to ſee you heere an Iron man
Chearing a rowt of Rebels with your Drumme,
Turning the Word, to Sword; and Life to death:
That man that ſits within a Monarches heart,
And ripens in the Sunne-ſhine of his fauor,
Would hee abuſe the Countenance of the King,
Alack, what Miſchiefes might hee ſet abroach,
In ſhadow of ſuch Greatneſſe? With you, Lord Biſhop,
It is euen ſo. Who hath not heard it ſpoken,
How deepe you were within the Bookes of Heauen?
To vs, the Speaker in his Parliament;
To vs, th’ imagine Voyce of Heauen it ſelfe:
The very Opener, and Intelligencer,
Betweene the Grace, the Sanƈtities of Heauen;
And our dull workings. O, who ſhall beleeue,
But you miſ-vſe the reuerence of your Place,
Employ the Countenance, and Grace of Heauen,
As a falſe Fauorite doth his Princes Name,
In deedes diſ-honorable? You haue taken vp,
Vnder the counterfeited Zeale of Heauen,
The Subieƈts of Heauens Subſtitute, my Father,
And both againſt the Peace of Heauen, and him,
Haue here vp-ſwarmed them.

speech.speaker: Biſh.
speech.line: Good my Lord of Lancaſter,
I am not here againſt your Fathers Peace:
But (as I told my Lord of Weſtmerland)
The Time (miſ-order’d) doth in common ſence
Crowd vs, and cruſh vs, to this monſtrous Forme,
To hold our ſafetie vp. I ſent your Grace
The parcels, and particulars of our Griefe,
The which hath been with ſcorne ſhou’d from the Court:
Whereon this Hydra-Sonne of Warre is borne,
Whoſe dangerous eyes may well be charm’d aſleepe,
With graunt of our moſt iuſt and right deſires;
And true Obedience, of this Madneſſe cur’d,
Stoope tamely to the foot of Maieſtie.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: If not, wee readie are to trye our fortunes,
To the laſt man.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: And though wee here fall downe,
Wee haue Supplyes, to ſecond our Attempt:
If they miſ-carry, theirs ſhall ſecond them.
And ſo, ſucceſſe of Miſchiefe ſhall be borne,
And Heire from Heire ſhall hold this Quarrell vp,
Whiles England ſhall haue generation.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: You are too ſhallow (Haſtings)
Much too ſhallow,
To ſound the bottome of the after-Times.

speech.speaker: Weſt.
speech.line: Pleaſeth your Grace, to anſwere them direƈtly,
How farre-forth you doe like their Articles.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: I like them all, and doe allow them well:
And ſweare here, by the honor of my blood,
My Fathers purpoſes haue beene miſtooke,
And ſome, about him, haue too lauiſhly
Wreſted his meaning, and Authoritie.
My Lord, theſe Griefes ſhall be with ſpeed redreſt:
Vpon my Life, they ſhall. If this may pleaſe you,
Diſcharge your Powers vnto their ſeuerall Counties,
As wee will ours: and here, betweene the Armies,
Let’s drinke together friendly, and embrace,
That all their eyes may beare thoſe Tokens home,
Of our reſtored Loue, and Amitie.

speech.speaker: Biſh.
speech.line: I take your Princely word, for theſe redreſſes.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: I giue it you, and will maintaine my word:
And thereupon I drinke vnto your Grace.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: Goe Captaine, and deliuer to the Armie
This newes of Peace: let them haue pay, and part:
I know, it will well pleaſe them.
High thee Captaine.

speech.speaker: Biſh.
speech.line: To you, my Noble Lord of Weſtmerland.

speech.speaker: Weﬆ.
speech.line: I pledge your Grace:
And if you knew what paines I haue beſtow’d,
To breede this preſent Peace,
You would drinke freely: but my loue to ye,
Shall ſhew it ſelfe more openly hereafter.

speech.speaker: Biſh.
speech.line: I doe not doubt you.

speech.speaker: Weſt.
speech.line: I am glad of it.
Health to my Lord, and gentle Couſin Mowbray.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: You wiſh me health in very happy ſeaſon,
For I am, on the ſodaine, ſomething ill.

speech.speaker: Biſh.
speech.line: Againſt ill Chances, men are euer merry,
But heauineſſe fore-runnes the good euent.

speech.speaker: Weſt.
speech.line: Therefore be merry (Cooze) ſince ſodaine ſorrow
Serues to ſay thus: ſome good thing comes to morrow.

speech.speaker: Biſh.
speech.line: Beleeue me, I am paſſing light in ſpirit.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: So much the worſe, if your owne Rule be true.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: The word of Peace is render’d: hearke how
they ſhowt.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: This had been chearefull, after Viƈtorie.

speech.speaker: Biſh.
speech.line: A Peace is of the nature of a Conqueſt:
For then both parties nobly are ſubdu’d,
And neither partie looſer.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: Goe (my Lord)
And let our Army be diſcharged too:
And good my Lord (ſo pleaſe you) let our Traines
March by vs, that wee may peruſe the men
Wee ſhould haue coap’d withall.

speech.speaker: Biſh.
speech.line: Goe, good Lord Haſtings:
And ere they be diſmiſs’d, let them march by.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: I truſt (Lords) wee ſhall lye to night together.
Now Couſin, wherefore ſtands our Army ſtill?

speech.speaker: Weﬆ.
speech.line: The Leaders hauing charge from you to ſtand,
Will not goe oﬀ, vntill they heare you ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Iohn
speech.line: They know their duties.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: Our Army is diſpers’d:
Like youthfull Steeres, vnyoak’d, they tooke their courſe
Eaſt, Weſt, North, South: or like a Schoole, broke vp,
Each hurryes towards his home, and ſporting place.

speech.speaker: Weſt.
speech.line: Good tidings (my Lord Haſtings) for the which,
I doe arreſt thee (Traytor) of high Treaſon:
And you Lord Arch-biſhop, and you Lord Mowbray,
Of Capitall Treaſon, I attach you both.

speech.speaker: Mow.
speech.line: Is this proceeding iuſt, and honorable?

speech.speaker: Weſt.
speech.line: Is your Aſſembly ſo?

speech.speaker: Biſh.
speech.line: Will you thus breake your faith?

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: I pawn’d thee none:
I promis’d you redreſſe of theſe ſame Grieuances
Whereof you did complaine; which, by mine Honor,
I will performe, with a moſt Chriſtian care.
But for you (Rebels) looke to taſte the due
Meet for Rebellion, and ſuch Aƈts as yours.
Moſt ſhallowly did you theſe Armes commence,
Fondly brought here, and fooliſhly ſent hence.
Strike vp our Drummes, purſue the ſcatter’d ſtray,
Heauen, and not wee, haue ſafely fought to day.
Some guard theſe Traitors to the Block of Death,
Treaſons true Bed, and yeelder vp of breath.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: What’s your Name, Sir? of what Condition are
you? and of what place, I pray?

speech.speaker: Col.
speech.line: I am a Knight, Sir:
And my Name is Colleuile of the Dale.

speech.speaker: Falﬆ.
speech.line: Well then, Colleuile is your Name, a Knight is
your Degree, and your Place, the Dale. Colleuile ſhall
ſtill be your Name, a Traytor your Degree, and the Dun-
geon your Place, a place deepe enough: ſo ſhall you be
ſtill Colleuile of the Dale.

speech.speaker: Col.
speech.line: Are not you Sir Iohn Falſtaﬀe?

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: As good a man as he ſir, who ere I am: doe yee
yeelde ſir, or ſhall I ſweate for you? if I doe ſweate, they
are the drops of thy Louers, and they weep for thy death,
therefore rowze vp Feare and Trembling, and do obſer-
uance to my mercy.

speech.speaker: Col.
speech.line: I thinke you are Sir Iohn Falſtaﬀe, & in that thought
yeeld me.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: I haue a whole Schoole of tongues in this belly of
mine, and not a Tongue of them all, ſpeakes anie other
word but my name: and I had but a belly of any indiﬀe-
rencie, I were ſimply the moſt aƈtiue fellow in Europe:
my wombe, my wombe, my wombe vndoes mee. Heere
comes our Generall.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: The heat is paſt, follow no farther now:
Call in the Powers, good Couſin Weﬆmerland.
Now Falﬆtaﬀe, where haue you beene all this while?
When euery thing is ended, then you come.
Theſe tardie Tricks of yours will (on my life)
One time, or other, breake ſome Gallowes back.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: I would bee ſorry (my Lord) but it ſhould bee
thus: I neuer knew yet, but rebuke and checke was the
reward of Valour. Doe you thinke me a Swallow, an Ar-
row, or a Bullet? Haue I, in my poore and olde Motion,
the expedition of Thought? I haue ſpeeded hither with
the very extremeſt ynch of poſſibilitie. I haue fowndred
nine ſcore and odde Poſtes: and heere (trauell-tainted
as I am) haue, in my pure and immaculate Valour, taken
Sir Iohn Colleuile of the Dale, a moſt furious Knight, and
valorous Enemie: But what of that? hee ſaw mee, and
yeelded: that I may iuſtly ſay with the hooke-nos’d
fellow of Rome, I came, ſaw, and ouer-came.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: It was more of his Courteſie, then your deſer-
uing.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: I know not: heere hee is, and heere I yeeld
him: and I beſeech your Grace, let it be book’d, with
the reſt of this dayes deedes; or I ſweare, I will haue it
in a particular Ballad, with mine owne Piƈture on the top
of it (Colleuile kiſſing my foot:) To the which courſe, if
I be enforc’d, if you do not all ſhew like gilt two-pences
to me; and I, in the cleare Skie of Fame, o’re-ſhine you
as much as the Full Moone doth the Cynders of the Ele-
ment (which ſhew like Pinnes-heads to her) beleeue not
the Word of the Noble: therefore let mee haue right,
and let deſert mount.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: Thine’s too heauie to mount.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Let it ſhine then.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: Thine’s too thick to ſhine.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Let it doe ſomething (my good Lord) that may
doe me good, and call it what you will.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: Is thy Name Colleuile?

speech.speaker: Col.
speech.line: It is (my Lord.)

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: A famous Rebell art thou, Colleuile.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: And a famous true Subieƈt tooke him.

speech.speaker: Col.
speech.line: I am (my Lord) but as my Betters are,
That led me hither: had they beene rul’d by me,
You ſhould haue wonne them dearer then you haue.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: I know not how they ſold themſelues, but thou
like a kinde fellow, gau’ſt thy ſelfe away; and I thanke
thee, for thee.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: Haue you left purſuit?

speech.speaker: Weſt.
speech.line: Retreat is made, and Execution ſtay’d.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: Send Colleuile, with his Confederates,
To Yorke, to preſent Execution.
Blunt, leade him hence, and ſee you guard him ſure.
And now diſpatch we toward the Court (my Lords)
I heare the King, my Father, is ſore ſicke.
Our Newes ſhall goe before vs, to his Maieſtie,
Which (Couſin) you ſhall beare, to comfort him:
And wee with ſober ſpeede will follow you.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: My Lord, I beſeech you, giue me leaue to goe
through Glouceſterſhire: and when you come to Court,
ſtand my good Lord, ’pray, in your good report.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: Fare you well, Falﬆaﬀe: I, in my condition,
Shall better ſpeake of you, then you deſerue.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: I would you had but the wit: ’twere better
then your Dukedome. Good faith, this ſame young ſo-
ber-blooded Boy doth not loue me, nor a man cannot
make him laugh: but that’s no maruaile, hee drinkes no
Wine. There’s neuer any of theſe demure Boyes come
to any proofe: for thinne Drinke doth ſo ouer-coole
their blood, and making many Fiſh-Meales, that they
fall into a kinde of Male Greene-ſickneſſe: and then,
when they marry, they get Wenches. They are generally
Fooles, and Cowards; which ſome of vs ſhould be too,
but for inﬂamation. A good Sherris-Sack hath a two-
fold operation in it: it aſcends me into the Braine, dryes
me there all the fooliſh, and dull, and cruddie Vapours,
which enuiron it: makes it apprehenſiue, quicke, forge-
tiue, full of nimble, ﬁerie, and deleƈtable ſhapes; which
deliuer’d o’re to the Voyce, the Tongue, which is the
Birth, becomes excellent Wit. The ſecond propertie of
your excellent Sherris, is, the warming of the Blood:
which before (cold, and ſetled) left the Liuer white, and
pale; which is the Badge of Puſillanimitie, and Cowar-
dize: but the Sherris warmes it, and makes it courſe
from the inwards, to the parts extremes: it illuminateth
the Face, which (as a Beacon) giues warning to all the
reſt of this little Kingdome (Man) to Arme: and then
the Vitall Commoners, and in-land pettie Spirits, muſter
me all to their Captaine, the Heart; who great, and puﬀt
vp with his Retinue, doth any Deed of Courage: and this
Valour comes of Sherris. So, that skill in the Weapon
is nothing, without Sack (for that ſets it a-worke:) and
Learning, a meere Hoord of Gold, kept by a Deuill, till
Sack commences it, and ſets it in aƈt, and vſe. Hereof
comes it, that Prince Harry is valiant: for the cold blood
hee did naturally inherite of his Father, hee hath, like
leane, ſtirrill, and bare Land, manured, husbanded, and
tyll’d, with excellent endeauour of drinking good, and
good ſtore of fertile Sherris, that hee is become very hot,
and valiant. If I had a thouſand Sonnes, the ﬁrſt Principle
I would teach them, ſhould be to forſweare thinne Pota-
tions, and to addiƈt themſelues to Sack. Enter Bardolph.
How now Bardolph?

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: The Armie is diſcharged all, and gone.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Let them goe: Ile through Glouceſterſhire,
and there will I viſit Maſter Robert Shallow, Eſquire: I
haue him alreadie tempering betweene my ﬁnger and my
thombe, and ſhortly will I ſeale with him. Come away.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Now Lords, if Heauen doth giue ſucceſſefull end
To this Debate, that bleedeth at our doores,
Wee will our Youth lead on to higher Fields,
And draw no Swords, but what are ſanƈtify’d.
Our Nauie is addreſſed, our Power colleƈted,
Our Subſtitutes, in abſence, well inueſted,
And euery thing lyes leuell to our wiſh;
Onely wee want a little perſonall Strength:
And pawſe vs, till theſe Rebels, now a-foot,
Come vnderneath the yoake of Gouernment.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Both which we doubt not, but your Maieſtie
Shall ſoone enioy.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Humphrey (my Sonne of Glouceſter) where is
the Prince, your Brother?

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: I thinke hee’s gone to hunt (my Lord) at Wind-
ſor.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: And how accompanied?

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: I doe not know (my Lord.)

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Is not his Brother, Thomas of Clarence, with
him?

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: No (my good Lord) hee is in preſence heere.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: What would my Lord, and Father?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Nothing but well to thee, Thomas of Clarence.
How chance thou art not with the Prince, thy Brother?
Hee loues thee, and thou do’ſt negleƈt him (Thomas.)
Thou haſt a better place in his Aﬀeƈtion,
Then all thy Brothers: cheriſh it (my Boy)
And Noble Oﬃces thou may’ſt eﬀeƈt
Of Mediation (after I am dead)
Betweene his Greatneſſe, and thy other Brethren.
Therefore omit him not: blunt not his Loue,
Nor looſe the good aduantage of his Grace,
By ſeeming cold, or careleſſe of his will.
For hee is gracious, if hee be obſeru’d:
Hee hath a Teare for Pitie, and a Hand
Open (as Day) for melting Charitie:
Yet notwithſtanding, being incens’d, hee’s Flint,
As humorous as Winter, and as ſudden,
As Flawes congealed in the Spring of day.
His temper therefore muſt be well obſeru’d:
Chide him for faults, and doe it reuerently,
When you perceiue his blood enclin’d to mirth:
But being moodie, giue him Line, and ſcope,
Till that his paſſions (like a Whale on ground)
Confound themſelues with working. Learne this Thomas,
And thou ſhalt proue a ſhelter to thy friends,
A Hoope of Gold, to binde thy Brothers in:
That the vnited Veſſell of their Blood
(Mingled with Venome of Suggeſtion,
As force, perforce, the Age will powre it in)
Shall neuer leake, though it doe worke as ſtrong
As Aconitum, or raſh Gun-powder.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: I ſhall obſerue him with all care, and loue.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Why art thou not at Windſor with him (Tho-
mas?)

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: Hee is not there to day: hee dines in Lon-
don.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: And how accompanyed? Canſt thou tell
that?

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: With Pointz, and other his continuall fol-
lowers.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Moſt ſubieƈt is the fatteſt Soyle to Weedes:
And hee (the Noble Image of my Youth)
Is ouer-ſpread with them: therefore my griefe
Stretches it ſelfe beyond the howre of death.
The blood weepes from my heart, when I doe ſhape
(In formes imaginarie) th’ vnguided Dayes,
And rotten Times, that you ſhall looke vpon,
When I am ſleeping with my Anceſtors.
For when his head-ſtrong Riot hath no Curbe,
When Rage and hot-Blood are his Counſailors,
When Meanes and lauiſh Manners meete together;
Oh, with what Wings ſhall his Aﬀeƈtions ﬂye
Towards fronting Perill, and oppos’d Decay?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: My gracious Lord, you looke beyond him quite:
The Prince but ſtudies his Companions,
Like a ſtrange Tongue: wherein, to gaine the Language,
’Tis needfull, that the moſt immodeſt word
Be look’d vpon, and learn’d: which once attayn’d,
Your Highneſſe knowes, comes to no farther vſe,
But to be knowne, and hated. So, like groſſe termes,
The Prince will, in the perfeƈtneſſe of time,
Caſt oﬀ his followers: and their memorie
Shall as a Patterne, or a Meaſure, liue,
By which his Grace muſt mete the liues of others,
Turning paſt-euills to aduantages.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: ’Tis ſeldome, when the Bee doth leaue her Combe
In the dead Carrion.
Who’s heere? Weſtmerland?

speech.speaker: Weſt.
speech.line: Health to my Soueraigne, and new happineſſe
Added to that, that I am to deliuer.
Prince Iohn, your Sonne, doth kiſſe your Graces Hand:
Mowbray, the Biſhop, Scroope, Haſtings, and all,
Are brought to the Correƈtion of your Law.
There is not now a Rebels Sword vnſheath’d,
But Peace puts forth her Oliue euery where:
The manner how this Aƈtion hath beene borne,
Here (at more leyſure) may your Highneſſe reade,
With euery courſe, in his particular.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: O Weſtmerland, thou art a Summer Bird,
Which euer in the haunch of Winter ſings
The lifting vp of day.
Looke, heere’s more newes.

speech.speaker: Harc.
speech.line: From Enemies, Heauen keepe your Maieſtie:
And when they ſtand againſt you, may they fall,
As thoſe that I am come to tell you of.
The Earle Northumberland, and the Lord Bardolfe,
With a great Power of Engliſh, and of Scots,
Are by the Sherife of Yorkeſhire ouerthrowne:
The manner, and true order of the ﬁght,
This Packet (pleaſe it you) containes at large.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: And wherefore ſhould theſe good newes
Make me ſicke?
Will Fortune neuer come with both hands full,
But write her faire words ſtill in fouleſt Letters?
Shee eyther giues a Stomack, and no Foode,
(Such are the poore, in health) or elſe a Feaſt,
And takes away the Stomack (ſuch are the Rich,
That haue aboundance, and enioy it not.)
I ſhould reioyce now, at this happy newes,
And now my Sight fayles, and my Braine is giddie.
O me, come neere me, now I am much ill.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Comfort your Maieſtie.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Oh, my Royall Father.

speech.speaker: Weſt.
speech.line: My Soueraigne Lord, cheare vp your ſelfe, looke
vp.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Be patient (Princes) you doe know, theſe Fits
Are with his Highneſſe very ordinarie.
Stand from him, giue him ayre:
Hee’le ſtraight be well.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: No, no, hee cannot long hold out: theſe pangs,
Th’ inceſſant care, and labour of his Minde,
Hath wrought the Mure, that ſhould conﬁne it in,
So thinne, that Life lookes through, and will breake out.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: The people feare me: for they doe obſerue
Vnfather’d Heires, and loathly Births of Nature:
The Seaſons change their manners, as the Yeere
Had found ſome Moneths aſleepe, and leap’d them ouer.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: The Riuer hath thrice ﬂow’d, no ebbe betweene:
And the old folke (Times doting Chronicles)
Say it did ſo, a little time before
That our great Grand-ſire Edward ſick’d, and dy’de.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Speake lower (Princes) for the King reco-
uers.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: This Apoplexie will (certaine) be his end.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I pray you take me vp, and beare me hence
Into ſome other Chamber: ſoftly ’pray.
Let there be no noyſe made (my gentle friends)
Vnleſſe ſome dull and fauourable hand
Will whiſper Muſicke to my wearie Spirit.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Call for the Muſicke in the other Roome.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Set me the Crowne vpon my Pillow here.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: His eye is hollow, and hee changes much.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Leſſe noyſe, leſſe noyſe.

speech.speaker: P. Hen.
speech.line: Who ſaw the Duke of Clarence?

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: I am here (Brother) full of heauineſſe.

speech.speaker: P. Hen.
speech.line: How now? Raine within doores, and none
abroad? How doth the King?

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Exceeding ill.

speech.speaker: P. Hen.
speech.line: Heard hee the good newes yet?
Tell it him.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Hee alter’d much, vpon the hearing it.

speech.speaker: P. Hen.
speech.line: If hee be ſicke with Ioy,
Hee’le recouer without Phyſicke.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Not ſo much noyſe (my Lords)
Sweet Prince ſpeake lowe,
The King, your Father, is diſpos’d to ſleepe.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: Let vs with-draw into the other Roome.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Wil’t pleaſe your Grace to goe along with vs?

speech.speaker: P. Hen.
speech.line: No: I will ſit, and watch here, by the King.
Why doth the Crowne lye there, vpon his Pillow,
Being ſo troubleſome a Bed-fellow?
O polliſh’d Perturbation! Golden Care!
That keep’ſt the Ports of Slumber open wide,
To many a watchfull Night: ſleepe with it now,
Yet not ſo ſound, and halfe ſo deepely ſweete,
As hee whoſe Brow (with homely Biggen bound)
Snores out the Watch of Night. O Maieſtie!
When thou do’ſt pinch thy Bearer, thou do’ſt ſit
Like a rich Armor, worne in heat of day,
That ſcald’ſt with ſafetie: by his Gates of breath,
There lyes a dowlney feather, which ſtirres not:
Did hee ſuſpire, that light and weightleſſe dowlne
Perforce muſt moue. My gracious Lord, my Father,
This ſleepe is ſound indeede: this is a ſleepe,
That from this Golden Rigoll hath diuorc’d
So many Engliſh Kings. Thy due, from me,
Is Teares, and heauie Sorrowes of the Blood,
Which Nature, Loue, and ﬁliall tenderneſſe,
Shall (O deare Father) pay thee plenteouſly.
My due, from thee, is this Imperiall Crowne,
Which (as immediate from thy Place, and Blood)
Deriues it ſelfe to me. Loe, heere it ſits,
Which Heauen ſhall guard:
And put the worlds whole ſtrength into one gyant Arme,
It ſhall not force this Lineall Honor from me.
This, from thee, will I to mine leaue,
As ’tis left to me.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Warwicke, Glouceſter, Clarence.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: Doth the King call?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: What would your Maieſtie? how fares your
Grace?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Why did you leaue me here alone (my Lords?)

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: We left the Prince (my Brother) here (my Liege)
Who vndertooke to ſit and watch by you.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: The Prince of Wales? where is hee? let mee
ſee him.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: This doore is open, hee is gone this way.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Hee came not through the Chamber where wee
ſtayd.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Where is the Crowne? who tooke it from my
Pillow?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: When wee with-drew (my Liege) wee left it
heere.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: The Prince hath ta’ne it hence:
Goe ſeeke him out.
Is hee ſo haſtie, that hee doth ſuppoſe
My ſleepe, my death? Finde him (my Lord of Warwick)
Chide him hither: this part of his conioynes
With my diſeaſe, and helpes to end me.
See Sonnes, what things you are:
How quickly Nature falls into reuolt,
When Gold becomes her Obieƈt?
For this, the fooliſh ouer-carefull Fathers
Haue broke their ſleepes with thoughts,
Their braines with care, their bones with induſtry.
For this, they haue ingroſſed and pyl’d vp
The canker’d heapes of ſtrange-atchieued Gold:
For this, they haue beene thoughtfull, to inueſt
Their Sonnes with Arts, and Martiall Exerciſes:
When, like the Bee, culling from euery ﬂower
The vertuous Sweetes, our Thighes packt with Wax,
Our Mouthes with Honey, wee bring it to the Hiue;
And like the Bees, are murthered for our paines.
This bitter taſte yeelds his engroſſements,
To the ending Father.
Now, where is hee, that will not ſtay ſo long,
Till his Friend Sickneſſe hath determin’d me?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: My Lord, I found the Prince in the next Roome,
Waſhing with kindly Teares his gentle Cheekes,
With ſuch a deepe demeanure, in great ſorrow,
That Tyranny, which neuer quaﬀt but blood,
Would (by beholding him) haue waſh’d his Knife
With gentle eye-drops. Hee is comming hither.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: But wherefore did hee take away the Crowne?
Loe, where hee comes. Come hither to me (Harry.)
Depart the Chamber, leaue vs heere alone.

speech.speaker: P. Hen.
speech.line: I neuer thought to heare you ſpeake againe.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Thy wiſh was Father (Harry) to that thought:
I ſtay too long by thee, I wearie thee.
Do’ſt thou ſo hunger for my emptie Chayre,
That thou wilt needes inueſt thee with mine Honors,
Before thy howre be ripe? O fooliſh Youth!
Thou ſeek’ſt the Greatneſſe, that will ouer-whelme thee.
Stay but a little: for my Cloud of Dignitie
Is held from falling, with ſo weake a winde,
That it will quickly drop: my Day is dimme.
Thou haſt ſtolne that, which after ſome few howres
Were thine, without oﬀence: and at my death
Thou haſt ſeal’d vp my expeƈtation.
Thy Life did manifeſt, thou lou’dſt me not,
And thou wilt haue me dye aſſur’d of it.
Thou hid’ſt a thouſand Daggers in thy thoughts,
Which thou haſt whetted on thy ſtonie heart,
To ſtab at halfe an howre of my Life.
What? canſt thou not forbeare me halfe an howre?
Then get thee gone, and digge my graue thy ſelfe,
And bid the merry Bels ring to thy eare
That thou art Crowned, not that I am dead.
Let all the Teares, that ſhould bedew my Hearſe
Be drops of Balme, to ſanƈtiﬁe thy head:
Onely compound me with forgotten duſt.
Giue that, which gaue thee life, vnto the Wormes:
Plucke downe my Oﬃcers, breake my Decrees;
For now a time is come, to mocke at Forme.
Henry the ﬁft is Crown’d: Vp Vanity,
Downe Royall State: All you ſage Counſailors, hence:
And to the Engliſh Court, aſſemble now
From eu’ry Region, Apes of Idleneſſe.
Now neighbor-Conﬁnes, purge you of your Scum:
Haue you a Ruﬃan that will ſweare? drinke? dance?
Reuell the night? Rob? Murder? and commit
The oldeſt ſinnes, the neweſt kinde of wayes?
Be happy, he will trouble you no more:
England, ſhall double gill’d, his trebble guilt.
England, ſhall giue him Oﬃce, Honor, Might:
For the Fift Harry, from curb’d Licenſe pluckes
The muzzle of Reſtraint; and the wilde Dogge
Shall ﬂeſh his tooth in euery Innocent.
O my poore Kingdome (ſicke, with ciuill blowes)
When that my Care could not with-hold thy Ryots,
What wilt thou do, when Ryot is thy Care?
O, thou wilt be a Wilderneſſe againe,
Peopled with Wolues (thy old Inhabitants.)

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: O pardon me (my Liege)
But for my Teares,
The moſt Impediments vnto my Speech,
I had fore-ſtall’d this deere, and deepe Rebuke,
Ere you (with greefe) had ſpoke, and I had heard
The courſe of it ſo farre. There is your Crowne,
And he that weares the Crowne immortally,
Long guard it yours. If I aﬀeƈt it more,
Then as your Honour, and as your Renowne,
Let me no more from this Obedience riſe,
Which my moſt true, and inward duteous Spirit
Teacheth this proſtrate, and exteriour bending.
Heauen witneſſe with me, when I heere came in,
And found no courſe of breath within your Maieſtie,
How cold it ſtrooke my heart. If I do faine,
O let me, in my preſent wildeneſſe, dye,
And neuer liue, to ſhew th’ incredulous World,
The Noble change that I haue purpoſed.
Comming to looke on you, thinking you dead,
(And dead almoſt (my Liege) to thinke you were)
I ſpake vnto the Crowne (as hauing ſenſe)
And thus vpbraided it. The Care on thee depending,
Hath fed vpon the body of my Father,
Therefore, thou beſt of Gold, art worſt of Gold.
Other, leſſe ﬁne in Charraƈt, is more precious,
Preſeruing life, in Med’cine potable:
But thou, moſt Fine, moſt Honour’d, moſt Renown’d,
Haſt eate the Bearer vp.
Thus (my Royall Liege)
Accuſing it, I put it on my Head,
To try with it (as with an Enemie,
That had before my face murdred my Father)
The Quarrell of a true Inheritor.
But if it did infeƈt my blood with Ioy,
Or ſwell my Thoughts, to any ſtraine of Pride,
If any Rebell, or vaine ſpirit of mine,
Did, with the leaſt Aﬀeƈtion of a Welcome,
Giue entertainment to the might of it,
Let heauen, for euer, keepe it from my head,
And make me, as the pooreſt Vaſſaile is,
That doth with awe, and terror kneele to it.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: O my Sonne!
Heauen put it in thy minde to take it hence,
That thou might’ſt ioyne the more, thy Fathers loue,
Pleading ſo wiſely, in excuſe of it.
Come hither Harrie, ſit thou by my bedde,
And heare (I thinke, the very lateſt Counſell
That euer I ſhall breath: Heauen knowes, my Sonne)
By what by-pathes, and indireƈt crook’d-wayes
I met this Crowne: and I my ſelfe know well
How troubleſome it ſate vpon my head.
To thee, it ſhall deſcend with better Quiet,
Better Opinion, better Conﬁrmation:
For all the ſoyle of the Atchieuement goes
With me, into the Earth. It ſeem’d in mee,
But as an Honour ſnatch’d with boyſt’rous hand,
And I had many liuing, to vpbraide
My gaine of it, by their Aſſiſtances,
Which dayly grew to Quarrell, and to Blood-ſhed,
Wounding ſuppoſed Peace.
All theſe bold Feares,
Thou ſeeſt (with perill) I haue anſwered:
For all my Reigne, hath beene but as a Scene
Aƈting that argument. And now my death
Changes the Moode: For what in me, was purchas’d,
Falles vpon thee, in a more Fayrer ſort.
So thou, the Garland wear’ſt ſucceſſiuely.
Yet, though thou ſtand’ſt more ſure, then I could do,
Thou art not ﬁrme enough, ſince greefes are greene:
And all thy Friends, which thou muſt make thy Friends
Haue but their ſtings, and teeth, newly tak’n out,
By whoſe fell working, I was ﬁrſt aduanc’d,
And by whoſe power, I well might lodge a Feare
To be againe diſplac’d. Which to auoyd,
I cut them oﬀ: and had a purpoſe now
To leade out many to the Holy Land;
Leaſt reſt, and lying ſtill, might make them looke
Too neere vnto my State.
Therefore (my Harrie)
Be it thy courſe to buſie giddy Mindes
With Forraigne Quarrels: that Aƈtion hence borne out,
May waſte the memory of the former dayes.
More would I, but my Lungs are waſted ſo,
That ſtrength of Speech it vtterly deni’de mee.
How I came by the Crowne, O heauen forgiue:
And grant it may, with thee, in true peace liue.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: My gracious Liege:
You wonne it, wore it: kept it, gaue it me,
Then plaine and right muſt my poſſeſſion be;
Which I, with more, then with a Common paine,
’Gainſt all the World, will rightfully maintaine.

scene.stagedir: Enter Lord Iohn of Lancaſter, and Warwicke.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Looke, looke,
Heere comes my Iohn of Lancaſter:

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: Health, Peace, and Happineſſe,
To my Royall Father.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Thou bring’ſt me happineſſe and Peace
(Sonne Iohn:)
But health (alacke) with youthfull wings is ﬂowne
From this bare, wither’d Trunke. Vpon thy ſight
My worldly buſineſſe makes a period.
Where is my Lord of Warwicke?

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: My Lord of Warwicke.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Doth any name particular, belong
Vnto the Lodging, where I ﬁrſt did ſwoon’d?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: ’Tis call’d Ieruſalem, my Noble Lord.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Laud be to heauen:
Euen there my life muſt end.
It hath beene propheſi’de to me many yeares,
I ſhould not dye, but in Ieruſalem:
Which (vainly) I ſuppos’d the Holy-Land.
But beare me to that Chamber, there Ile lye:
In that Ieruſalem, ſhall Harry dye.

scene.stagedir: Enter Shallow, Silence, Falſtaﬀe, Bardolfe, Page, and Dauie.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: By Cocke and Pye, you ſhall not away to night.
What Dauy, I ſay.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: You muſt excuſe me, M. Robert Shallow.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: I will not excuſe you: you ſhall not be excuſed.
Excuſes ſhall not be admitted: there is no excuſe ſhall
ſerue: you ſhall not be excus’d.
Why Dauie.

speech.speaker: Dauie.
speech.line: Heere ſir.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Dauy, Dauy, Dauy, let me ſee (Dauy) let me ſee:
William Cooke, bid him come hither. Sir Iohn, you ſhal
not be excus’d.

speech.speaker: Dauy.
speech.line: Marry ſir, thus: thoſe Precepts cannot bee
ſeru’d: and againe ſir, ſhall we ſowe the head-land with
Wheate?

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: With red Wheate Dauy. But for William Cook:
are there no yong Pigeons?

speech.speaker: Dauy.
speech.line: Yes Sir.
Heere is now the Smithes note, for Shooing,
And Plough-Irons.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Let it be caſt, and payde: Sir Iohn, you ſhall
not be excus’d.

speech.speaker: Dauy.
speech.line: Sir, a new linke to the Bucket muſt needes bee
had: And Sir, doe you meane to ſtoppe any of Williams
Wages, about the Sacke he loſt the other day, at Hinckley
Fayre?

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: He ſhall anſwer it:
Some Pigeons Dauy, a couple of ſhort-legg’d Hennes: a
ioynt of Mutton, and any pretty little tine Kickſhawes,
tell William Cooke.

speech.speaker: Dauy.
speech.line: Doth the man of Warre, ſtay all night ſir?

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Yes Dauy:
I will vſe him well. A Friend i’th Court, is better then a
penny in purſe. Vſe his men well Dauy, for they are ar-
rant Knaues, and will backe-bite.

speech.speaker: Dauy.
speech.line: No worſe then they are bitten, ſir: For they
haue maruellous fowle linnen.

speech.speaker: Shallow.
speech.line: Well conceited Dauy: about thy Buſineſſe,
Dauy.

speech.speaker: Dauy.
speech.line: I beſeech you ſir,
To countenance William Viſor of Woncot, againſt Cle-
ment Perkes of the hill.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: There are many Complaints Dauy, againſt that
Viſor, that Viſor is an arrant Knaue, on my know-
ledge.

speech.speaker: Dauy.
speech.line: I graunt your Worſhip, that he is a knaue (Sir:)
But yet heauen forbid Sir, but a Knaue ſhould haue ſome
Countenance, at his Friends requeſt. An honeſt man ſir,
is able to ſpeake for himſelfe, when a Knaue is not. I haue
ſeru’d your Worſhippe truely ſir, theſe eight yeares: and
if I cannot once or twice in a Quarter beare out a knaue,
againſt an honeſt man, I haue but a very litle credite with
your Worſhippe. The Knaue is mine honeſt Friend Sir,
therefore I beſeech your Worſhip, let him bee Counte-
nanc’d.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Go too,
I ſay he ſhall haue no wrong: Looke about Dauy.
Where are you Sir Iohn? Come, oﬀ with your Boots.
Giue me your hand M. Bardolfe.

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: I am glad to ſee your Worſhip.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: I thanke thee, with all my heart, kinde Maſter
Bardolfe: and welcome my tall Fellow:
Come Sir Iohn.

speech.speaker: Falſtaﬀe.
speech.line: Ile follow you, good Maſter Robert Shallow.
Bardolfe, looke to our Horſſes. If I were ſaw’de into
Quantities, I ſhould make foure dozen of ſuch bearded
Hermites ſtaues, as Maſter Shallow. It is a wonderfull
thing to ſee the ſemblable Coherence of his mens ſpirits,
and his: They, by obſeruing of him, do beare themſelues
like fooliſh Iuſtices: Hee, by conuerſing with them, is
turn’d into a Iuſtice-like Seruingman. Their ſpirits are
ſo married in Coniunƈtion, with the participation of So-
ciety, that they ﬂocke together in conſent, like ſo ma-
ny Wilde-Geeſe. If I had a ſuite to Mayſter Shallow, I
would humour his men, with the imputation of beeing
neere their Mayſter. If to his Men, I would currie with
Maiſter Shallow, that no man could better command his
Seruants. It is certaine, that either wiſe bearing, or ig-
norant Carriage is caught, as men take diſeaſes, one of
another: therefore, let men take heede of their Compa-
nie. I will deuiſe matter enough out of this Shallow, to
keepe Prince Harry in continuall Laughter, the wearing
out of ſixe Faſhions (which is foure Tearmes) or two Ac-
tions, and he ſhall laugh with Interuallums. O it is much
that a Lye (with a ſlight Oath) and a ieſt (with a ſadde
brow) will doe, with a Fellow, that neuer had the Ache
in his ſhoulders. O you ſhall ſee him laugh, till his Face
be like a wet Cloake, ill laid vp.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Sir Iohn.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: I come Maſter Shallow, I come Maſter Shallow.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Earle of Warwicke, and the Lord Chiefe Iuſtice.

speech.speaker: Warwicke.
speech.line: How now, my Lord Chiefe Iuſtice, whe-
ther away?

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: How doth the King?

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Exceeding well: his Cares
Are now, all ended.

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: I hope, not dead.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Hee’s walk’d the way of Nature,
And to our purpoſes, he liues no more.

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: I would his Maieſty had call’d me with him,
The ſeruice, that I truly did his life,
Hath left me open to all iniuries.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Indeed I thinke the yong King loues you not.

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: I know he doth not, and do arme my ſelfe
To welcome the condition of the Time,
Which cannot looke more hideouſly vpon me,
Then I haue drawne it in my fantaſie.

scene.stagedir: Enter Iohn of Lancaſter, Glouceﬆer, and Clarence.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Heere come the heauy Iſſue of dead Harrie:
O, that the liuing Harrie had the temper
Of him, the worſt of theſe three Gentlemen:
How many Nobles then, ſhould hold their places,
That muſt ſtrike ſaile, to Spirits of vilde ſort?

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: Alas, I feare, all will be ouer-turn’d.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: Good morrow Coſin Warwick, good morrow.

speech.speaker: Glou. Cla.
speech.line: Good morrow, Coſin.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: We meet, like men, that had forgot to ſpeake.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: We do remember: but our Argument
Is all too heauy, to admit much talke.

speech.speaker: Ioh.
speech.line: Well: Peace be with him, that hath made vs heauy

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: Peace be with vs, leaſt we be heauier.

speech.speaker: Glou.
speech.line: O, good my Lord, you haue loſt a friend indeed:
And I dare ſweare, you borrow not that face
Of ſeeming ſorrow, it is ſure your owne.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: Though no man be aſſur’d what grace to ﬁnde,
You ſtand in coldeſt expeƈtation.
I am the ſorrier, would ’twere otherwiſe.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Wel, you muſt now ſpeake Sir Iohn Falﬆaﬀe faire,
Which ſwimmes againſt your ſtreame of Quality.

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: Sweet Princes: what I did, I did in Honor,
Led by th’ Imperiall Conduƈt of my Soule,
And neuer ſhall you ſee, that I will begge
A ragged, and fore-ſtall’d Remiſſion.
If Troth, and vpright Innocency fayle me,
Ile to the King (my Maſter) that is dead,
And tell him, who hath ſent me after him.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Heere comes the Prince.

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: Good morrow: and heauen ſaue your Maieſty

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: This new, and gorgeous Garment, Maieſty,
Sits not ſo eaſie on me, as you thinke.
Brothers, you mixe your Sadneſſe with ſome Feare:
This is the Engliſh, not the Turkiſh Court:
Not Amurah, an Amurah ſucceeds,
But Harry, Harry: Yet be ſad (good Brothers)
For (to ſpeake truth) it very well becomes you:
Sorrow, ſo Royally in you appeares,
That I will deeply put the Faſhion on,
And weare it in my heart. Why then be ſad,
But entertaine no more of it (good Brothers)
Then a ioynt burthen, laid vpon vs all.
For me, by Heauen (I bid you be aſſur’d)
Ile be your Father, and your Brother too:
Let me but beare your Loue, Ile beare your Cares;
But weepe that Harrie’s dead, and ſo will I.
But Harry liues, that ſhall conuert thoſe Teares
By number, into houres of Happineſſe.

speech.speaker: Iohn, &c.
speech.line: We hope no other from your Maieſty.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: You all looke ſtrangely on me: and you moſt,
You are (I thinke) aſſur’d, I loue you not.

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: I am aſſur’d (if I be meaſur’d rightly)
Your Maieſty hath no iuſt cauſe to hate mee.

speech.speaker: Pr.
speech.line: No? How might a Prince of my great hopes forget
So great Indignities you laid vpon me?
What? Rate? Rebuke? and roughly ſend to Priſon
Th’ immediate Heire of England? Was this eaſie?
May this be waſh’d in Lethe, and forgotten?

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: I then did vſe the Perſon of your Father:
The Image of his power, lay then in me,
And in th’ adminiſtration of his Law,
Whiles I was buſie for the Commonwealth,
Your Highneſſe pleaſed to forget my place,
The Maieſty, and power of Law, and Iuſtice,
The Image of the King, whom I preſented,
And ſtrooke me in my very Seate of Iudgement:
Whereon (as an Oﬀender to your Father)
I gaue bold way to my Authority,
And did commit you. If the deed were ill,
Be you contented, wearing now the Garland,
To haue a Sonne, ſet your Decrees at naught?
To plucke downe Iuſtice from your awefull Bench?
To trip the courſe of Law, and blunt the Sword
That guards the peace, and ſafety of your Perſon?
Nay more, to ſpurne at your moſt Royall Image,
And mocke your workings, in a Second body?
Queſtion your Royall Thoughts, make the caſe yours:
Be now the Father, and propoſe a Sonne:
Heare your owne dignity ſo much prophan’d,
See your moſt dreadfull Lawes, ſo looſely ſlighted;
Behold your ſelfe, ſo by a Sonne diſdained:
And then imagine me, taking your part,
And in your power, ſoft ſilencing your Sonne:
After this cold conſiderance, ſentence me;
And, as you are a King, ſpeake in your State,
What I haue done, that misbecame my place,
My perſon, or my Lieges Soueraigntie.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: You are right Iuſtice, and you weigh this well:
Therefore ſtill beare the Ballance, and the Sword:
And I do wiſh your Honors may encreaſe,
Till you do liue, to ſee a Sonne of mine
Oﬀend you, and obey you, as I did.
So ſhall I liue, to ſpeake my Fathers words:
Happy am I, that haue a man ſo bold,
That dares do Iuſtice, on my proper Sonne;
And no leſſe happy, hauing ſuch a Sonne,
That would deliuer vp his Greatneſſe ſo,
Into the hands of Iuſtice. You did commit me:
For which, I do commit into your hand,
Th’ vnſtained Sword that you haue vs’d to beare:
With this Remembrance; That you vſe the ſame
With the like bold, iuſt, and impartiall ſpirit
As you haue done ’gainſt me. There is my hand,
You ſhall be as a Father, to my Youth:
My voice ſhall ſound, as you do prompt mine eare,
And I will ſtoope, and humble my Intents,
To your well-praƈtis’d, wiſe Direƈtions.
And Princes all, beleeue me, I beſeech you:
My Father is gone wilde into his Graue,
(For in his Tombe, lye my Aﬀeƈtions)
And with his Spirits, ſadly I ſuruiue,
To mocke the expeƈtation of the World;
To fruſtrate Propheſies, and to race out
Rotten Opinion, who hath writ me downe
After my ſeeming. The Tide of Blood in me,
Hath prowdly ﬂow’d in Vanity, till now.
Now doth it turne, and ebbe backe to the Sea,
Where it ſhall mingle with the ſtate of Floods,
And ﬂow henceforth in formall Maieſty.
Now call we our High Court of Parliament,
And let vs chooſe ſuch Limbes of Noble Counſaile,
That the great Body of our State may go
In equall ranke, with the beſt gouern’d Nation,
That Warre, or Peace, or both at once may be
As things acquainted and familiar to vs,
In which you (Father) ſhall haue formoſt hand.
Our Coronation done, we will accite
(As I before remembred) all our State,
And heauen (conſigning to my good intents)
No Prince, nor Peere, ſhall haue iuſt cauſe to ſay,
Heauen ſhorten Harries happy life, one day.

scene.stagedir: Enter Falſtaﬀe, Shallow, Silence, Bardolfe, Page, and Piſtoll.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Nay, you ſhall ſee mine Orchard: where, in an
Arbor we will eate a laſt yeares Pippin of my owne graf-
ﬁng, with a diſh of Carrawayes, and ſo forth. (Come Co-
ſin Silence, and then to bed.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: You haue heere a goodly dwelling, and a rich.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Barren, barren, barren: Beggers all, beggers all
Sir Iohn: Marry, good ayre. Spread Dauy, ſpread Dauie:
Well ſaid Dauie.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: This Dauie ſerues you for good vſes: he is your
Seruingman, and your Husband.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: A good Varlet, a good Varlet, a very good Var-
let, Sir Iohn: I haue drunke too much Sacke at Supper. A
good Varlet. Now ſit downe, now ſit downe: Come
Coſin.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Ah ſirra (quoth-a) we ſhall doe nothing but eate,
and make good cheere, and praiſe heauen for the merrie
yeere: when ﬂeſh is cheape, and Females deere, and luſtie
Lads rome heere, and there: ſo merrily, and euer among
ſo merrily.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: There’s a merry heart, good M. Silence, Ile giue
you a health for that anon.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Good M. Bardolfe: ſome wine, Dauie.

speech.speaker: Da.
speech.line: Sweet ſir, ſit: Ile be with you anon: moſt ſweete
ſir, ſit. Maſter Page, good M. Page, ſit: Proface. What
you want in meate, wee’l haue in drinke: but you beare,
the heart’s all.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Be merry M. Bardolfe, and my little Souldiour
there, be merry.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Be merry, be merry, my wife ha’s all.
For women are Shrewes, both ſhort, and tall:
’Tis merry in Hall, when Beards wagge all;
And welcome merry Shrouetide. Be merry, be merry.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: I did not thinke M. Silence had bin a man of this
Mettle.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Who I? I haue beene merry twice and once, ere
now.

speech.speaker: Dauy.
speech.line: There is a diſh of Lether-coats for you.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Dauie.

speech.speaker: Dau.
speech.line: Your Worſhip: Ile be with you ſtraight. A cup
of Wine, ſir?

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: A Cup of Wine, that’s briske and ﬁne, & drinke
vnto the Leman mine: and a merry heart liues long-a.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Well ſaid, M. Silence.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: If we ſhall be merry, now comes in the ſweete of
the night.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Health, and long life to you, M. Silence.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Fill the Cuppe, and let it come. Ile pledge you a
mile to the bottome.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Honeſt Bardolfe, welcome: If thou want’ſt any
thing, and wilt not call, beſhrew thy heart. Welcome my
little tyne theefe, and welcome indeed too: Ile drinke to
M. Bardolfe, and to all the Cauileroes about London.

speech.speaker: Dau.
speech.line: I hope to ſee London, once ere I die.

speech.speaker: Bar.
speech.line: If I might ſee you there, Dauie.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: You’l cracke a quart together? Ha, will you not
M. Bardolfe?

speech.speaker: Bar.
speech.line: Yes Sir, in a pottle pot.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: I thanke thee: the knaue will ſticke by thee, I
can aſſure thee that. He will not out, he is true bred.

speech.speaker: Bar.
speech.line: And Ile ſticke by him, ſir.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Why there ſpoke a King: lack nothing, be merry.
Looke, who’s at doore there, ho: who knockes?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Why now you haue done me right.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Do me right, and dub me Knight, Samingo. Is’t
not ſo?

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: ’Tis ſo.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Is’t ſo? Why then ſay an old man can do ſomwhat.

speech.speaker: Dau.
speech.line: If it pleaſe your Worſhippe, there’s one Piſtoll
come from the Court with newes.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: From the Court? Let him come in.
How now Piſtoll?

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: Sir Iohn, ’saue you ſir.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: What winde blew you hither, Piſtoll?

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: Not the ill winde which blowes none to good,
ſweet Knight: Thou art now one of the greateſt men in
the Realme.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: Indeed, I thinke he bee, but Goodman Puﬀe of
Barſon.

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: Puﬀe? puﬀe in thy teeth, moſt recreant Coward
baſe. Sir Iohn, I am thy Piſtoll, and thy Friend: helter
skelter haue I rode to thee, and tydings do I bring, and
luckie ioyes, and golden Times, and happie Newes of
price.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: I prethee now deliuer them, like a man of this
World.

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: A footra for the World, and Worldlings baſe,
I ſpeake of Aﬀrica, and Golden ioyes.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: O baſe Aſſyrian Knight, what is thy newes?
Let King Couitha know the truth thereof.

speech.speaker: Sil.
speech.line: And Robin-hood, Scarlet, and Iohn.

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: Shall dunghill Curres confront the Hellicons?
And ſhall good newes be baﬀel’d?
Then Piſtoll lay thy head in Furies lappe.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Honeſt Gentleman,
I know not your breeding.

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: Why then Lament therefore.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Giue me pardon, Sir.
If ſir, you come with news from the Court, I take it, there
