is but two wayes, either to vtter them, or to conceale
them. I am Sir, vnder the King, in ſome Authority.

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: Vnder which King?
Bezonian, ſpeake, or dye.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Vnder King Harry.

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: Harry the Fourth? or Fift?

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: Harry the Fourth.

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: A footra for thine Oﬃce.
Sir Iohn, thy tender Lamb-kinne, now is King,
Harry the Fift’s the man, I ſpeake the truth.
When Piſtoll lyes, do this, and ﬁgge-me, like
The bragging Spaniard.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: What, is the old King dead?

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: As naile in doore.
The things I ſpeake, are iuſt.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Away Bardolfe, Sadle my Horſe,
Maſter Robert Shallow, chooſe what Oﬃce thou wilt
In the Land, ’tis thine. Piſtol, I will double charge thee
With Dignities.

speech.speaker: Bard.
speech.line: O ioyfull day:
I would not take a Knighthood for my Fortune.

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: What? I do bring good newes.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Carrie Maſter Silence to bed: Maſter Shallow, my
Lord Shallow, be what thou wilt, I am Fortunes Steward.
Get on thy Boots, wee’l ride all night. Oh ſweet Piſtoll:
Away Bardolfe: Come Piſtoll, vtter more to mee: and
withall deuiſe ſomething to do thy ſelfe good. Boote,
boote Maſter Shallow, I know the young King is ſick for
mee. Let vs take any mans Horſſes: The Lawes of Eng-
land are at my command’ment. Happie are they, which
haue beene my Friendes: and woe vnto my Lord Chiefe
Iuſtice.

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: Let Vultures vil’de ſeize on his Lungs alſo:
Where is the life that late I led, ſay they?
Why heere it is, welcome thoſe pleaſant dayes.

scene.stagedir: Enter Hoſteſſe Quickly, Dol Teare-ſheete, and Beadles.

speech.speaker: Hoſteſſe.
speech.line: No, thou arrant knaue: I would I might dy,
that I might haue thee hang’d: Thou haſt drawne my
ſhoulder out of ioynt.

speech.speaker: Oﬀ.
speech.line: The Conſtables haue deliuer’d her ouer to mee:
and ſhee ſhall haue Whipping cheere enough, I warrant
her. There hath beene a man or two (lately) kill’d about
her.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Nut-hooke, nut-hooke, you Lye: Come on, Ile
tell thee what, thou damn’d Tripe-viſag’d Raſcall, if the
Childe I now go with, do miſcarrie, thou had’ſt better
thou had’ſt ſtrooke thy Mother, thou Paper-fac’d Vil-
laine.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: O that Sir Iohn were come, hee would make
this a bloody day to ſome body. But I would the Fruite
of her Wombe might miſcarry.

speech.speaker: Oﬀicer.
speech.line: If it do, you ſhall haue a dozen of Cuſhions
againe, you haue but eleuen now. Come, I charge you
both go with me: for the man is dead, that you and Pi-
ſtoll beate among you.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Ile tell thee what, thou thin man in a Cenſor; I
will haue you as ſoundly ſwindg’d for this, you blew-
Bottel’d Rogue: you ﬁlthy famiſh’d Correƈtioner, if you
be not ſwing’d, Ile forſweare halfe Kirtles.

speech.speaker: Oﬀ.
speech.line: Come, come, you ſhee-Knight-arrant, come.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: O, that right ſhould thus o’recome might. Wel
of ſuﬀerance, comes eaſe.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Come you Rogue, come:
Bring me to a Iuſtice.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: Yes, come you ſtaru’d Blood-hound.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Goodman death, goodman Bones.

speech.speaker: Hoſt.
speech.line: Thou Anatomy, thou.

speech.speaker: Dol.
speech.line: Come you thinne Thing:
Come you Raſcall.

speech.speaker: Oﬀ.
speech.line: Very well.

speech.speaker: 1. Groo.
speech.line: More Ruſhes, more Ruſhes.

speech.speaker: 2. Groo.
speech.line: The Trumpets haue ſounded twice.

speech.speaker: 1. Groo.
speech.line: It will be two of the Clocke, ere they come
from the Coronation.

scene.stagedir: Enter Falſtaﬀe, Shallow, Piſtoll, Bardolfe, and Page.

speech.speaker: Falſtaﬀe.
speech.line: Stand heere by me, M. Robert Shallow, I will
make the King do you Grace. I will leere vpon him, as
he comes by: and do but marke the countenance that hee
will giue me.

speech.speaker: Piſtol.
speech.line: Bleſſe thy Lungs, good Knight.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Come heere Piſtol, ſtand behind me. O if I had
had time to haue made new Liueries, I would haue be-
ſtowed the thouſand pound I borrowed of you. But it is
no matter, this poore ſhew doth better: this doth inferre
the zeale I had to ſee him.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: It doth ſo.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: It ſhewes my earneſtneſſe in aﬀeƈtion.

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: It doth ſo.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: My deuotion.

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: It doth, it doth, it doth.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: As it were, to ride day and night,
And not to deliberate, not to remember,
Not to haue patience to ſhift me.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: It is moſt certaine.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: But to ſtand ſtained with Trauaile, and ſweating
with deſire to ſee him, thinking of nothing elſe, putting
all aﬀayres in obliuion, as if there were nothing els to bee
done, but to ſee him.

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: ’Tis ſemper idem: for obſque hoc nihil eﬆ. ’Tis all
in euery part.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: ’Tis ſo indeed.

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: My Knight, I will enﬂame thy Noble Liuer, and
make thee rage. Thy Dol, and Helen of thy noble thoghts
is in baſe Durance, and contagious priſon: Hall’d thi-
ther by moſt Mechanicall and durty hand. Rowze vppe
Reuenge from Ebon den, with fell Aleƈto’s Snake, for
Dol is in. Piſtol, ſpeakes nought but troth.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: I will deliuer her.

speech.speaker: Piſtol.
speech.line: There roar’d the Sea: and Trumpet Clangour
ſounds.

scene.stagedir: The Trumpets ſound. Enter King Henrie the Fift, Brothers, Lord Chiefe Iuſtice.

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Saue thy Grace, King Hall, my Royall Hall.

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: The heauens thee guard, and keepe, moſt royall
Impe of Fame.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: ’Saue thee my ſweet Boy.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: My Lord Chiefe Iuſtice, ſpeake to that vaine
man.

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: Haue you your wits?
Know you what ’tis you ſpeake?

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: My King, my Ioue; I ſpeake to thee, my heart.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I know thee not, old man: Fall to thy Prayers:
How ill white haires become a Foole, and Ieſter?
I haue long dream’d of ſuch a kinde of man,
So ſurfeit-ſwell’d, ſo old, and ſo prophane:
But being awake, I do deſpiſe my dreame.
Make leſſe thy body (hence) and more thy Grace,
Leaue gourmandizing; Know the Graue doth gape
For thee, thrice wider then for other men.
Reply not to me, with a Foole-borne Ieſt,
Preſume not, that I am the thing I was,
For heauen doth know (so ſhall the world perceiue)
That I haue turn’d away my former Selfe,
So will I thoſe that kept me Companie.
When thou doſt heare I am, as I haue bin,
Approach me, and thou ſhalt be as thou was’t
The Tutor and the Feeder of my Riots:
Till then, I baniſh thee, on paine of death,
As I haue done the reſt of my Miſleaders,
Not to come neere our Perſon, by ten mile.
For competence of life, I will allow you,
That lacke of meanes enforce you not to euill:
And as we heare you do reforme your ſelues,
We will according to your ſtrength, and qualities,
Giue you aduancement. Be it your charge (my Lord)
To ſee perform’d the tenure of our word. Set on.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Maſter Shallow, I owe you a thouſand pound.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: I marry Sir Iohn, which I beſeech you to let me
haue home with me.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: That can hardly be, M. Shallow, do not you grieue
at this: I ſhall be ſent for in priuate to him: Looke you,
he muſt ſeeme thus to the world: feare not your aduance-
ment: I will be the man yet, that ſhall make you great.

speech.speaker: Shal.
speech.line: I cannot well perceiue how, vnleſſe you ſhould
giue me your Doublet, and ſtuﬀe me out with Straw. I
beſeech you, good Sir Iohn, let mee haue ﬁue hundred of
my thouſand.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Sir, I will be as good as my word. This that you
heard, was but a colour.

speech.speaker: Shall.
speech.line: A colour I feare, that you will dye in, Sir Iohn.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: Feare no colours, go with me to dinner:
Come Lieutenant Piﬆol, come Bardolfe,
I ſhall be ſent for ſoone at night.

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: Go carry Sir Iohn Falſtaﬀe to the Fleete,
Take all his Company along with him.

speech.speaker: Fal.
speech.line: My Lord, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: I cannot now ſpeake, I will heare you ſoone:
Take them away.

speech.speaker: Piſt.
speech.line: Si fortuna me tormento, ſpera me contento.

scene.stagedir: Exit. Manent Lancaſter and Chiefe Iuſtice.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: I like this faire proceeding of the Kings:
He hath intent his wonted Followers
Shall all be very well prouided for:
But all are baniſht, till their conuerſations
Appeare more wiſe, and modeſt to the world.

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: And ſo they are.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: The King hath call’d his Parliament,
My Lord.

speech.speaker: Ch. Iuſt.
speech.line: He hath.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: I will lay oddes, that ere this yeere expire,
We beare our Ciuill Swords, and Natiue ﬁre
As farre as France. I heare a Bird ſo ſing,
Whoſe Muſicke (to my thinking) pleas’d the King.
Come, will you hence?

epilogue.line: FIRST, my Feare: then, my Curtſie: last, my Speech.
My Feare, is your Displeaſure: My Curtſie, my Dutie:
And my speech, to Begge your Pardons. If you looke for a
good speech now, you vndoe me: For what I haue to ſay, is
of mine owne making: and what (indeed) I ſhould ſay, will
(I doubt) prooue mine owne marring. But to the Purpoſe,
and ſo to the Venture. Be it knowne to you (as it is very
well) I was lately heere in the end of a displeaſing Play, to pray your Patience
for it, and to promiſe you a Better: I did meane (indeede) to pay you with this,
which if (like an ill Venture) it come vnluckily home, I breake; and you, my gen-
tle Creditors loſe. Heere I promiſt you I would be, and heere I commit my Bodie
to your Mercies: Bate me ſome, and I will pay you ſome, and (as moſt Debtors do)
promiſe you inﬁnitely.
If my Tongue cannot entreate you to acquit me: will you command me to vſe
my Legges? And yet that were but light payment, to Dance out of your debt: But
a good Conſcience, will make any poſsible ſatisfaƈtion, and ſo will I. All the Gen-
tlewomen heere, haue forgiuen me, if the Gentlemen will not, then the Gentlemen
do not agree with the Gentlewomen, which was neuer ſeene before, in ſuch an Aſ-
ſembly.
One word more, I beſeech you: if you be not too much cloid with Fat Meate,
our humble Author will continue the Story (with Sir Iohn in it) and make you
merry, with faire Katherine of France: where (for any thing I know) Fal-
ſtaﬀe ſhall dye of a ſweat, vnleſſe already he be kill’d with your hard Opinions:
For Old-Caſtle dyed a Martyr, and this is not the man. My Tongue is wearie,
when my Legs are too, I will bid you good night; and ſo kneele downe before you;
But (indeed) to pray for the Queene.

personae.persona: Prince Henry, afterwards Crowned King Henrie the Fift.

personagroup.title: Sonnes to Henry the Fourth, & brethren to Henry 5.
Oppoſites againſt King Henrie the Fourth.
